properties.Name: Cedarlake (Cedar Lake)
properties.Summary: Cedar Lake was a "Negro Colony" that was apparently backed by wealthy white elites, such as English millionaire, Lillian K. Ray. Booker T. Washington spoke at its opening.

properties.Name: Freetown
properties.Summary: Freetown was a community established by free Black people in 1867. In the 1920s Freetown was absorbed by the newly incorporated town of Allenville. In 2005 efforts to remember Freetown as a historic designation commenced. Descendants of Freetown and the Collins and Jefferies families have organized around the town.

properties.Name: Greenwood Village
properties.Summary: Greenwood Village is listed in Hamilton's 1991 book on Black Towns. Greenwood is a neighborhood in Bessemer, Alabama which is a majority Black city near Birmingham, AL.

properties.Name: Hobson City (Mooree Quarters)
properties.Summary: Alabama's first black self-governed municipality founded in 1899.

properties.Name: Kowaliga (Benson)
properties.Summary: John Benson was a former slave of James Benson. As a young adult John worked in a coal mine and earned enough money to lease land from the Benson plantation. By 1898 John owned 3000 acres of his own at Kowaliga Creek. John's son William E. Benson went on to found Kowaliga School which educated rural Black children for three decades. The town was "drowned" in 1926 when Martin Dam was completed on the Tallapoosa River to form Lake Martin.

properties.Name: Plateau
properties.Summary: Also called "Africatown." Founded 1860s. Formed by 32 West Africans who were the last slaves sent to the US on the Clotilda. Historic District. Living Descedants, including Questlove.

properties.Name: Roosevelt City
properties.Summary: Roosevelt was a Black Town near Birmingham. Likely the town grew as a residence for Black workers in Birmingham manufacturing industry. In 1988 the town voted to be annexed into Birmingham.

properties.Name: Tuskegee
properties.Summary: Founded 1833. Loads of information on the experiment from the public health sector

properties.Name: White Hall
properties.Summary: Potentially previously called "Tent City." Previously a plantation, established during the Great Depression. Only passing mentionings of White Hall in literature

properties.Name: Henry McKee Island (Guntersville)
properties.Summary: It is believed that there was a Black Town where the Tennessee Valley Authority constructed the Guntersville Dam and reservoir to create Lake Martin. It is clear that this dam project was established over Native American burial grounds (shell mounds). Henry McKee was a slaveowner, who owned Robert Smalls and his mother Lydia Polite at the Ashdale Plantation. Robert Smalls escaped from slavery and went on to be a notable figure.

properties.Name: Dempsey
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Original town Valdez renamed "Dempsey" after Melvin Dempsey, an African/Cherokee merchant and prospector in ~1900. This man was amazing. Town originally called Chisna? Anthony Goldstein, Curator of Collections and Exhibitions at the Valdez Museum, at curator@valdezmuseum.org

properties.Name: Mobile
properties.Summary: Founded 1930s for African Americans. Area also called Sonoran Valley. Mark T. Swanson a good author for AAs in the southwest. City is building a parkway to Mobile, the area is also home to landfill sites. Looks abandoned.

properties.Name: Randolph
properties.Summary: Founded by Epes Randolph, a white railroad engineer in the 1920s. Residents who migrated from Oklahoma and other places, trying to escape the Dust Bowl. Referred to as "historic"

properties.Name: Blackville
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Founded 1891 by Pickens Black Sr., former slave who migrated from Alabama and established his own town. 8,000 acres southeast of Newport, AR

properties.Name: Edmondson
properties.Summary: This town is named after Andrew Edmondson, who was likely a white settler. Sometime in the late 1860s Patrick Henry Ward (P. H. Ward), a former VA slave, moved to Edmonson and started a farm with his family. Ward went on to own nearly 500 acres in the area. The Ward family were large proponents of incorporating the town of Edmonson in 1911. The community became populated by African Americans who were working on the railroad nearby.

properties.Name: Lake View
properties.Summary: Not to be confused with "Lakeview" in Baxter county. Originally called "Turkey Scratch" in the 1850s. This one and two others were set aside for black families by the Resettlement Administration. Close to Elaine, AR (site of Elaine Race Massacre) which also might be a black town.

properties.Name: Menifee
properties.Summary: Founded 1820s, probably not by a black settler. Incorporated 1966.

properties.Name: Thomasville
properties.Summary: Potentially in Spring Creek Township, nothing but fields, a few houses and a black church called New Hope Missionary Baptist Church on Lee Road 116. 1860s it existed? Only a few mentionings of it in the literature. Possible lead?

properties.Name: Little Liberia
properties.Summary: "Little Liberia" was the name the LA Times gave to the Black agricultural settlement in Baja California. The town was started by James Littlejohn, who was hired by the then govenor of Baja California to build a highway, along with Black Angelenos, Black migrants from Oklahomoa, and through the Lower California Mexican Land and Development Company (Hooton, 2017, p. 65). By 1918 the company had over 25,000 acres of land (Hooton, 2017, p. 66). The land company went bankrupt in 1927 and Mexico seized the land. Many of the residents moved back to the U.S. and lost land as they didn't have Mexican citizenship. Littlejohn and a few other who had citizenship remained in Mexico in Ensenada (Hooton, 2017, p. 74). Location point near "Vallecitos" Baja California per poster by Hooton

properties.Name: Strathcona / Hogan's Alley (Vancouver)
properties.Summary: Black Strathcona/ Hogan's Alley was the name of an early 1900s Black community in Vancouver called Lane Park. The area follows the history of hundreds of Black people who migrated from California to British Columbia in 1858, approximately 500 stayed in BC after the US civil war. At the turn of the century Vancouver became the center of BC and the first Black man migrated to Vancouver in 1902. The historic Hogan's Alley was named in 1910 and was a prominent area for Black residence and social life until it was demolished by 1960s urban redevelopment and the building of freeways through the area. The redevelopment was fiercely contested by Black residents and Strathcona tenants association.

properties.Name: Saltspring / Salt Springs Island (Canada)
properties.Summary: A Black settlement emerged on Salt Springs Island in British Columbia consisting largely of Black migrants from the SF Exodus of 1858. Location points to Starks Rd.

properties.Name: Abila
properties.Summary: Abila (mostly referred to as a Black "colony") located in Los Angeles, south of Watts. In 1902, Charles Watts sold a tract of land to Pacific Electric (PE) Company, which created an area known as the Watts Junction and Abila Junction. Abila developed as a small, independent Black farming community. Abila remained a distinct community from Watts even as the Black population in Watts began to grow to one of the largest in California (by 1920 the Black population in Watts was more than 14%). The naming of the area makes it difficult to locate historical records as Abila is often confused with and overshadowed by Watts' history. Both Watts and Abila are also referred to as Mudtown. Abila lost its distiction when Watts was annexed to the city of Los Angeles in the 1920s.

properties.Name: Allensworth
properties.Summary: Located in California's San Joaquin Valley, Allensworth was founded in 1908 by the all-Black California Colony and Home Promoting Association. The town is named after Allen Allensworth, a man born into slavery in Louisville, KY who escaped and joined the Army during the Civil War. Allensworth rose to the rank of lieutenant colonel. Allensworth was an active member in the association and a key initiator of the town's establishment. At the time of establishment the association did not have enough money to purchase land, so they entered an agreement to secure 80 acres from 3 white-owned companies: the Central Land Company, the Los Angeles Purchasing Company, and the Pacific Farming Company. Summarized from K. M. Hamilton (1991), pgs. 138-148.

properties.Name: Beckwourth
properties.Summary: Not sure that this meets the qualifications of a Black town. It appears to be a town named after a Black man, James Pierson Beckwourth (also known as James Beckwith, Jim Beckwourth, or James Beckworth) who travelled to CA during the Gold Rush. Beckwourth joined the Crow Nation initially as a captive in 1828 and later became a member of the nation. He married (at least one) woman from the Crow Nation and had several children. A trail that Beckwourth worked in the Sierra Nevada was later named after him (Beckwourth Pass) and the present day town of Beckwourth is more than 90% white.

properties.Name: Beulah
properties.Summary: This does not appear to be a Black town but rather a rest home for Black Christian elders that was established in Oakland in 1913.

properties.Name: Bowles
properties.Summary: Bowles was one of the four earliest independent Black towns established in California before the 1920s. Bowles is just four miles from Fowler in the San Joaquin Valley of California (Bakken & Kindell, 2006). Bakken and Kindell cite two other nearby areas that were Black populated but not independent Black towns: Visalia, Hanford, and Wasco - a Black "colony" established by white people in 1907.

properties.Name: El Centro
properties.Summary: Located in Imperial Valley, the southernmost county of California, the city of El Centro was incorporated in 1908. In the early 1900s Black migrants to California were enticed by the cotton ranches and land prospects in the Imperial Valley. In 1913 El Centro opened a separate all-Black school, which attracted individuals such as William Payne from Allenswoth to serve as principal. In 1918 a Black company, Calexico Investment Company, was formed to organize Black communities in the valley into a formal Black colony. El Centro's Black community reached 500 families by 1930, however due to racism and segregation it did not develop into an all-Black town and lost its distinction by the end of the same decade.

properties.Name: Fowler
properties.Summary: Fowler was established in 1890 by Black farmers interested in establishing an agricultural settlement the San Joaquin Valley (Bakken & Kindell, 2006). By the early 1900s the town had 30-40 Black families living there.

properties.Name: Furlong Tract
properties.Summary: In the early 1800s (before 1815), 44 Black people formed El Pueblo de Nuestra Senora la Reina de Los Angeles de Porciuncula in present-day Los Angeles. The  pueblo grew and by 1900 there were 2,200 Black people living in the area. In 1905, Black people (likely descendants of the pueblo community?) bought land from an Irish farmer named James Furlong to form the Furlong Tract. The Furlong Tract was bordered by Long Beach Avenue and Alameda, 50th and 55th streets. By 1910 the area had over 200 Black families and opened its first school for Black children. Many homes were damaged in the Long Beach earthquake of 1933, and in the 1940s the single-family homes were torn down to build a low-income housing project - Pueblo del Rio.

properties.Name: Imperial Valley
properties.Summary: A number of Black communities were established in the southern California region known as Imperial Valley, which encompasses the towns of Brawley, El Centro and Calexico. Bakken & Kindell refer to "Imperial Valley towns" that were developed in relation to cotton ranches around El Centro and Imperial. In 1923 a separate school was established in the city of Imperial for Black students and Black parents protested against racial segregation. The data included are for the city of Imperial itself, though it does not appear that this city was ever a Black town.

properties.Name: John Nobles Ranch (Coachella Valley)
properties.Summary: John and Miranda Nobles migrated from Oaklahoma to Indio in the Coachella Valley of southern California in 1922 at a time when they were restricted from purchasing land. In the 1930s Dr. Reynaldo Carreon apparently gifted his ranch to the couple. The Nobles encouraged and helped other Black people leaving Oklahoma to find a home in Indio by sharing their land. This created a Black neighborhood named after the ranch. "Over the years, Nobles� ranch evolved into a neighborhood with dozens of homes, apartments, three churches and a few stores. When John Nobles died in the late 1940s the ranch was left to his granddaughter who sold it a few years later." (Gail Arlene Ito, BlackPast, 2011). In 1987 the Indio Redevelopment Agency relocated 94 (all or mostly Black) households from the neighborhood in order to develop the Indio Fashion Mall (see Daniel Akst, Los Angeles Times, 1992 Aug 18) The coordinates point to John Noble Ave in Indio, California for the time being until the exact coordinates of the John Nobles Ranch can be located.

properties.Name: Kentucky Ridge
properties.Summary: In 1850, white slaveowner Colonel William F. English sold his Geogia plantation and attempted to establish a slave colony in California. He transported some 30+ enslaved Black people from Georgia to Philadelphia where they travelled via steamship to California (Commodor Stockton steamship). The party arrived in San Francisco on April 20, 1851. In 1851 he established Kentucky Ridge Mine in Nevada County, CA - which was a quartz and gold mine operated entirely by slave labor. A slave colony of Black men and women formed around the mine along Deer Creek. The men mined while the women washed. Some reports indicate that white miners felt there was an unfair advantage of having Black/enslaved laborers. English was killed in 1853 at which time the Black laborers gained freedom and moved into grass Valley and Nevada city (Lapp, 1977, pg. 75). The mine operated from 1851-1852. Coordinates for the mine are: 39.2485046, -121.1332866.

properties.Name: Negro Bar (Folsom)
properties.Summary: Negro Bar, later known as Granite city and now Folsom, was a Black mining town located in Sacramento County, California. In 1844, William Leidesdorff (a noteable Black figure in Calfornia history) received a land grant from the Mexican government for Rancho Rio de los Americanos for a total of 35,521 acres (see a historical map here). Leidesdorff was born in St. Croix and was of Black, danish, and indigenous (carrib) descent. Leidesdorff owned and operated a bar for Black miners during the California Gold Rush era which gave the area its name (it was also referred to as "N*gger Bar). Leidesdorff died suddenly at the age of 38 in 1848 which left his large estate in arrays. The estate was to pass to Leidesdorff's Black and carrib mother, Anna Marie Spark, who was in St. Croix. It seems she was swindled by Joseph Folsom into selling the property for much less than the value. She lost suit because she was not a U.S. "citizen".

properties.Name: Val Verde
properties.Summary: Val Verde was an all-Black town located near Valencia in southern California. Faced with racial segregation and exclusion in the Los Angeles area, in 1924 Sidney Jones (a prominent Black realtor) purchased 30 acres of land in the Santa Clarita Valley with the vision of establishing an all-Black resort community. Black people had previously attempted to establish Black beaches and swimming pools in the area but were unsucessful. Val Verde was marketed as "Eureka Villa" with a Eureka Villa Improvement Association that offered 700 lots. The area became a prominent retreat town for wealthier Black Americans and is often refferred to as the "Black Palm Springs". When recreation facilities opened to Black people in Los Angeles Val Verde's Black population declined due to its distance from the city.

properties.Name: Victorville
properties.Summary: "In the early 1900s, the black Los Angeles Forum learned that the federal government had opened homesteads in Sidewinder Valley, near the community of Victorville. A substantial colony, including prominent Los Angeles residents and Southern migrants, moved to the area, setting up farms and homes. By 1914, they had claimed 20,000 acres and were filing claims for more in nearby Victor Valley. But by 1920, many of the original settlers had left, discouraged by the shortage of water and the difficulty of converting desert into profitable cropland... By the end of that decade, the distinct black colony had ended, and blacks simply became a portion of the population of Victorville." (Bakken & Kindell, 2006)

properties.Name: Weed
properties.Summary: Weed is a town located in rural northern California in Siskiyou County. It was established in 1897 as a lumber mill town. In 1916 the Long-Bell Lumber Company offered to ship Black workers to the area. The Long-Bell Lumber Company had previously operated in Louisiana until 1922. "By 1920, Weed had 447 blacks; by 1930, 541, nearly all clustered in one part of the town with separate businesses and social institutions that they set up." (Bakken & Kindell, 2006, pg. 2).

properties.Name: Westmont
properties.Summary: Westmont (or West Athens/Westmont) is an unincorporated area in south Los Angeles where over 50% of the population is Black.

properties.Name: West Rancho Dominguez
properties.Summary: West Rancho Dominguez is a predominately Black community in south Los Angeles near Compton. Of a total population of 5,669 at the 2010 census, more than 50% were Black. In 2000 it was more than 67% Black. The Smart family (Joshua and Sarah J. Smart) moved to Los Angeles from Rhode Island in the 1850s. The Smarts became very wealthy and invested in real estate in old Rancho Dominguez. Until 1940 the area was known as "N*gger Slough" by white people.

properties.Name: View Park-Windsor Hills
properties.Summary: View Park-Windsor Hills is an unincorporated area in Los Angeles near Black historic cultural areas such as Fox Hills, Leimert Park, and Slauson Avenue. The neighborhood is a predominately middle-class Black community and is along the same corridor as other wealthy Black neighborhoods, Baldwin Hills and Ladera Heights. This is also a prominent area for Black entreprenuers. The area developed as a Black community due to racially restrictive covenants in Los Angeles. In 2016 View Park was listed on the national register of historic places due to its significance to Black history.

properties.Name: Dearfield
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Classified as a ghost town with abandoned wooden buildings around. Founded by Oliver Toussaint Jackson who began advertising for "colonists" in 1910 and declined during the Dustbowl. Registered as a Historic Place.

properties.Name: Belltown
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Historic Place designated in 1982, the Norwood House. Founded by "colored" man named Jacob Bell in the 1840s. Lots of photos scattered around the internet

properties.Name: Charley Town (Townsend)
properties.Summary: No longer black, but the town exists. Founded by a black man named Charles Lloyd in the 1800s before white Townsend brothers bought up land. History of this town looks white washed now.

properties.Name: Little Hell
properties.Summary: There was also a Little Heaven, which is said to have been set up for Irish workers, whereas Little Hell was for African Americans working on Jonathan Willis' fruit plantation. DE. Little Hell "vanished."

properties.Name: Polktown
properties.Summary: Intertwined with Civil War history, Colored troops graves found near the Chesapeake and Delaware Branch Canal. Looks like the area is now Delaware City

properties.Name: Star Hill
properties.Summary: Early black settlement by the 1860s, a stop on the Underground Railroad. Star Hill AME is on the National Register, added 1994.

properties.Name: Adderleyville
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Founded by George Adderley, an immigrant from the Bahamas. his home is on the National Register, added 1992. Located in Marathon, FL which is on the Florida Keys. Very small population, supposedly 6-10 house holds but I can't find source

properties.Name: American Beach
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Founded in 1935 by Florida's first black millionaire Abraham Lincoln Lewis. Black Vacation spot. Historic District designation in 2002.

properties.Name: Angola
properties.Summary: Maroon community established by 1812, pre-Florida history. Today it's the city of Bradenton. Archaeological data present.

properties.Name: Bland
properties.Summary: North of Alachua, early 1840s cotton farmers' community, ties to Whoopi Goldberg. There is still a community who meets, though I'm not clear if they all still live in Bland. Check back what "existing" req. means.

properties.Name: Bookertown
properties.Summary: The Black community at Bookertown was established around 1885 when Black railroad workers moved to the area. The first Black school was established in 1898 and in 1906 Black residents began to build houses. The town was named after Booker T. Washington. There is a park still there, currently NW of Sanford on Rt 4. It might still be black! News article saying its black. Nearby town of Sanford was 30% black near 2010. According to this Orlando Sentinel article, they were celery farmers, roads named after famous black men.

properties.Name: Bultersville
properties.Summary: Nothing, recheck spelling

properties.Name: Eatonville
properties.Summary: Historic District. Incorporated 1887. First all-black self-governing municipalities. Home of Zora Neale Hurston.  2,301 pop. (2018)

properties.Name: Fort Mose
properties.Summary: Oldest free black settlement in the US! Near St. Augustine. Established 1738-1820. ~100 person population.

properties.Name: Freedtown
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Pasco County. Founded by former enslaved man Benjiman Baisden. Community (a few families) left after a freeze in the 1890s, some to Dade City after. Descendant still alive today, potentially a community that still meets. There's a Marker designating Freetown as a significant place.

properties.Name: Hannibal Square
properties.Summary: Neighborhood in Winter Park, FL which is incorporated and majority white. Borders Eatonville. Established 1881 as a place for AA families who serviced white families.  Check what "existing" means.

properties.Name: Lincolnville
properties.Summary: Lincoln Historical District, established by freedmen in St. Augustine after the Civil War. In 1991 it was added to the register of historic places.

properties.Name: Nassauville (Fernandina, Amelia Island, American Beach)
properties.Summary: This town's history is also recorded under the names/aliases of Fernandina, Amelia Island, American Beach which are all in Nassau County, Florida. Black communities lived on Amelia Island since slavery and at least by the 1880s Black institution were creeated. In 1923 the Afro-American Life Insurance company created the Black beach town of American Beach, west of Nassauvile. Mt. Olive Missionary Baptist Church on National Register of Historic Places in 1998.

properties.Name: Parramore
properties.Summary: South of Eatonville and Winter Park, referred to as historical district, also borders Griffin Park Historic District. Made for black families.

properties.Name: Pilaklikaha
properties.Summary: North of Dade City/Freedtown.  Established in 1813 by Black Seminoles. Name means �many ponds� in the Mikasuki language. Pilaklikaha was the largest and most prosperous Black Seminole town in Florida. ~100 people. Also called "Abrahams Town." Waymarker.

properties.Name: Prospect Bluff (Negro Fort in Prospect Bluff)
properties.Summary: Also known as Fort Gadsden, along with a number of other names, such as Negro Fort by Americans later. Populated by fugitive slaves and Choctaws. Battle site and Massacre. South was mad that there was a place where slaves could escape to freedom into Spanish Florida so Andrew Jackson attacked it. One source says 800 fugitives. Historic site trail. Fort built 1814 though.

properties.Name: Rosewood
properties.Summary: Prosperous Black community that revolved around lumber prior to Rosewood Massacre. Originally white and black, apparently, before it was all black. 1923 massacre. 355 at peak. 200-355 people.

properties.Name: Royal
properties.Summary: Also called Picketsville. Looks like people still meet. First settlers from the Old Green Plantation, had a school and mail

properties.Name: Santos
properties.Summary: Established prior to the 1930s. Case of strural racism where the town nearly disbanded due to construction of a canal. Nelson source says that there is still a small community there that meets, population of 47 in 1886, and a few businesses and churches. Seems like it was established by white settlers, then a few black families moved in. Now there's just a Santos Trailhead and "Little Chapel United Methodist church on Southeast 80th Street"

properties.Name: Oscarville
properties.Summary: Oscarville was a small Black agricultural community established in 1870 in Forsyth County, Georgia. The town was known for the farmers who overcame a boll weevil infestation that tormented GA farmers during the Great Depression (Rojas, 2021). In 1912 the town was a site of racial cleansing, when three Black males accused of raping a white girl were lynched and white mobs followed to drive out the towns more than 1000 Black residents (Phillips, 2016). The town was destroyed to construct Lake Lanier, which was first filled in 1959.

properties.Name: Piney Grove
properties.Summary: Buckhead community, Piney Grove Cemetery still intact, across the street from luxury condos. The Piney Grove Missionary Baptist Church was demolished after storm in 1996. 1830s potentially as a founding date. 300 graves. MDJ source says other black areas such as Johnstown existed in the Atlanta/Buckhead area- in need of further investigation.

properties.Name: Rhodes Creek
properties.Summary: Black-founded. 1860 African Americans engaging in trades like mining and trapping. Named after William "Billy" or "Blackie" Rhodes, who was probably mulatto/mixed and had a fortune of $80k (Probably around $3 million today) and founded Rhodes Creek. It was a claim, but I don't think it was a black town...

properties.Name: Brooklyn
properties.Summary: Also called "Lovejoy" after the lynching of Elijah Lovejoy, 1820s settlement for fugitive slaves. Source states its the first black town to be incorporated in the year 1873. Oral histories recorded somewhere.

properties.Name: Cairo
properties.Summary: Southernmost city of IL, I don't think this qualifies as a BT, less than half population 1900s. Declared a Historic District in 1970 and mostly abandonded now.  Famous lynching here in 1909 of Will James, it's said that racial tensions were high here. Fun fact: Charles Darwin visited and wasn't impressed. 2010  ~71.5% black out of 2,831 people.

properties.Name: Miller Grove
properties.Summary: Freed slave settlement, and stop on the underground railroad. Slaveholder freed his slaves and brought them here. 1844-1920s decline. Oral histories were collected, archaeology sites. Cheryl LaRoche might have wrote on this town. Population peaked 1900s with 108 people.

properties.Name: New Philadelphia
properties.Summary: Black-founded. First town founed/registered by a freedman, named �Free Frank� McWorter. Mixed-raced community. National Register of Historic Places 2005. I know Paul Shackel, the anthropologist who studied New Philly.

properties.Name: Pin Oak Colony
properties.Summary: Event coming up in October (last check source)!! 1820s it looks like, established by Edward Coles who seemed to be a white slave-owner. He freed his slaves and was a safehaven for black people as an antislavery proponent. Stop on the underground railroad.

properties.Name: Robbins
properties.Summary: One of the oldest incorporated (in 1917) black towns and oldest black suburb in Chicago. Wikipedia says " first mayor was Thomas J. Kellar, who noted in an early interview "Our people in Robbins are mostly people who get tired of the white fights and the crowded city. They come out here to raise chickens, make gardens, and be a little more free". Established by (white?) Henry and Eugene Robbins who sold land to working-class blacks.

properties.Name: Rocky Fork
properties.Summary: Located in Godfrey, IL. Safehaven for fugitives and a stop on the Underground Railroad. Oral histories. Chapter 1 of LaRoche's book is about Rocky Fork. Early 1800s/1816. Church set up in 1863 by Erasmus green, according to video source.

properties.Name: Africa
properties.Summary: South of Rockport, IN. Spencer Co. Sandale Cemetery black cemetery. Is this Little Africa too? Difficult to find info on this place. Make note: Many of the people who migrated to Indiana towns below came from North Carolina!

properties.Name: Beck's Mill
properties.Summary: First glance history looks white washed, Indiana source says there's three black settlements, African Methodist Episcopal Cemetery (where John Williams is buried). Salem, Washington, Indiana African-American Cemetery in Becks Mill, Indiana. I don't think this qualifies.

properties.Name: Beech (Settlement)
properties.Summary: There's a Beech Grove a few miles away, not the same. Established by Quakers, Ridley Township, in the 1830s. 400 person peak population right outside of Carthage, a few families. Rush County for one source.

properties.Name: Bethel
properties.Summary: Coordinates near a Bethel Church and Cemetary which are on the National Register! News source says it was a stop on the underground railroad and that there is a three-page account titled Underground Railroad Station at Bethe in the book, �Historical Sketches of the Wabash Valley� by J. Wesley Whicker. " Source says �Negro gang that lived in the woods on the Todd farm east of Attica.� Census records also list names of a few free black persons that lived in Fountain County before the Civil War. Of course, the names of fugitive slaves living in the area at that time would not appear in census records." According to the National Register, there were 20-25 cabins, and a former servant to Day Crockett (fun fact).

properties.Name: Brownstown
properties.Summary: 98% white 2010 Census. Google results are questionably racist/racial? From Snopes: In July 1948, a �soldiers reunion and homecoming� held in the public square in Brownstown, Indiana, was advertised in the Jackson County Banner with the exhortation �Make this big week your vacation time � Bring the family � meet old friends � Hit the �Nigger Babies� � Eat Hot Dogs � Join the Fun.� I don't think this qualifies. Platted 1816.

properties.Name: Burnett
properties.Summary: Just a mentioning of it near Otter Creek in source. Coords near Rio Grande Baptist Church. Settlement potentially outside of Indiana State in Otter Creek area (doesn't show up on map). "The Burnett Settlement in Otter Creek (Cord) was established about 1835 and was named after its founder, Stephen Grove Burnett, a white man. Local resident Dorothy Ross described Burnett as flowing into Lost Creek and like Lost Creek, Burnett�s black residents also came from North Carolina. Their surnames included Stewart, Walden, Malone, Chandler and Roberts. Otter Creek Township�s population in 1850 was 80, with Nevins Township 46 and Lost Creek Township 138." (Source)

properties.Name: Cabin Creek
properties.Summary: Many settlers from North Carolina, connections to Quakers. Maybe 1834.

properties.Name: Cherry Grove
properties.Summary: Knox County black settlement located in southern Busseron Township. A Cherry Grove is also coming up far north in Indiana. Two Mariah/Maria Christian Churches. Some houses still around the area, Census on Wiki says its 98% white now. Allegedly part of the Underground Railroad, according to source.

properties.Name: Graysville
properties.Summary: Another Graysville in Sullivan County. In Jefferson County, 2�3 miles north of Hanover, active church, school, and several cemeteries. Potentially also here a man name George Evans, an African American stationmaster at Greenbrier (there's a Greenbrier Road). Early 1800s. Connection to Underground railroad.

properties.Name: Greenville
properties.Summary: Another Greenville elsewhere that was incorpotated in 1879. This Greenville Settlement is in Randolph Co. Source says it was the first of "such settlements"

properties.Name: Hanover
properties.Summary: Literally two miles south of Graysville... I bet its the same(ish) community. Church source says there may be a connection. Hanover College nearby... probbaly thr adjacent black community. Church on the National Register. Majority white today but the Church and possibly community is still active. Maybe mid-1800s.

properties.Name: Huggart
properties.Summary: Black-founded? This one actually came up on Google! According to its IN.gov marker: "First land purchased by Huggart brothers in 1834; area settled and farmed by their families and several other African-American households circa 1850-1890s. Settlement families attended nearby schools and churches and worked with neighbors in surrounding areas. Many residents were buried in nearby Porter-Rea Cemetery now in Potato Creek State Park." Considered the first rural African American settlement in northern Indiana.Settled by two Huggart brothers in 1834, very small. .

properties.Name: Leatherwood
properties.Summary: Little known about this place. Parke County. Seems to be a collection of smaller settlements, discrepancies about the who and when question; if AAs were here prior to the Civil War. "A man named Lewis Artis and others acquired a parcel of land for religious and school purposes for the colored population living in Leatherwood," according to Tribune Star source.

properties.Name: Lick Creek
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Hoosier State Park, lots of information available. Orange county. Also called  Little Africa, South Africa, and Paddy's Garden. Three African Americans bought land in1832. By 1855, the settlement reached its maximum size of 1,557 acres and 1862 marks its decline. Cemetary still there, 38.493620, -86.393869 might be more accurate coords.

properties.Name: Lost Creek
properties.Summary: There is apparently a rich history documented here, according to source, or at least people have heard of it. Vigo County. Seems like a community still meets, Lost Creek Grove Community in the Haute Terre area. Descendants still around, not sure if it counts as a "yes" but they still live in the area. Early 1800s.

properties.Name: Lyles Station
properties.Summary: Black-founded. Two freed slaves, the Lyles brothers purchased the land in the 1840s with help from Quakers. Living istorical school and museum present. One of the last remaining standing black Indiana settlements. Located in Gibson County. 800 residents at peak. Descendants still there. Objects from Lyles station on exhibit at NMAAHC!

properties.Name: Newport
properties.Summary: Not coming up... coordinates drop you in Fountain City, maybe 60 miles east from Indianapolis. Town founded by white man named Levi Coffin who helped AAs escape and was piviotal in the UGRR, as he and his wife Catherine helped ~3k fugitive slaves escape. I don't think this qualifies, however it deserves an honorable mention as the "grand central station" of the UGRR.

properties.Name: Pinkston
properties.Summary: Black-founded small settlement bought for $365 in 1857 by Emanuel Pinkston, who was born free. Far south of the Haute Terre region, ten miles west of Hoosier National Forest. Only a few, maybe five families lived there. Allegedly called "Colored Freedom."

properties.Name: Richland
properties.Summary: Multiple places. There's a Richland that is SW of Louiville Kentucky, S of Route 64. Seems to be the same coordinates as the "Richland City" listed on Wiki which is currently 99% white. There's a Richland County, OH with a prominent AA community? Found it: coordinates are in Jennings County, IN. Place called Richland or "Africa"  located south of the City of Vernon. "The Richland Settlement land is now part of the Crosley State Fish and Wildlife Area. A cemetery with remnants of a few headstones is all that remains" (IN Source).

properties.Name: Roberts (Settlement)
properties.Summary: Coordinates take you to the Roberts Chapel Cemetery directly north of Indianappolis. Website says "...African-American pioneer farm settlement. It was founded in 1835 by free blacks of mixed racial heritage who migrated mostly from North Carolina and Virginia to escape deteriorating racial conditions in the South." National Register/Historic designation. Notable figure Carl G. Roberts, a Chicago surgeon one of the first African Americans to be elected to the American College of Surgeons and a former president of the National Medical Association

properties.Name: Roundtree
properties.Summary: Listed in conjunction with Lyles Station, but Roundtree is coming up as a surname here. Having trouble finding evidence beyond it being near LS. IN History source says it's near the Patoka River, also: "James Roundtree is the name most associated with this community. He and others built the Black Bridge.  Later when it needed to be repaired, he fought and won a case that went to the Indiana Supreme Court." I'm wondering if it's where the Roundtrees settled? More research required.

properties.Name: Rush
properties.Summary: Ervin Township, school and Methodist Church mentioned but perhaps no longer standing. Possible cemetery. One source also mentions a nearby BASSETT settlement? Footprints source states: "A brief published history says the settlement was named for the Rev. Rush, who founded the church there. He was a �devout and spiritual man, well-versed in the Bible, though entirely unable to read or write" (19).

properties.Name: Salt Creek Township
properties.Summary: Decatur County, not seeing much. White now, little history mentioned anywhere

properties.Name: Sand Hill
properties.Summary: Also in conjunction with Lyles Station. IN Source says: "The settlement of Sand Hill was located below Lyles Station.  The Hardiman and Nolcox families are two early pioneers associated with this black rural community.  Both families are still farming in Gibson County." Similar issues as found with Roundtree. More research required.

properties.Name: Snelling
properties.Summary: Fugit Township, also Decatur. IN Source says: "Decatur County was organized in 1822 and about the same time, a free black man from Kentucky named Joseph Snelling purchased 56 acres of land in Fugit Township located in the northeastern corner of Decatur County.  Fugit Township was the area in the county that was settled earliest. This area became the beginning of a large free black community known as the Snelling Settlement." Could this and Salt Creek be related? Possible unnamed cemetery in area.

properties.Name: Snow Hill
properties.Summary: Randolph County. Source states: "Snow Hill�s first settler was Gabriel Moore who arrived about 1838. Other settlers in Snow Hill were Copeland, Winburn, Small, Boon, Lawrence, Winn, Watkins, Culfer, Benson and Bragg. Tucker gives profiles of William and Michael Benson, both were born in slavery in North Carolina and arrived in Randolph County via earlier settlement in Wayne County."

properties.Name: Underwood
properties.Summary: "...Linton Township. It was settled by John Underwood in1841; the same year the township was formed, and most likely came out of part of adjoining Honey Creek Township. John Underwood was said to have purchased large tracts of fertile land. Early residents of the settlement, like those in Lost Creek, were free blacks who emigrated from North Carolina and Virginia (Lyda). The other names associated with the Underwood settlement include Thomas, Manuel, Roberts, Harris, Russell and Bell. Their citizens provided a subscription school for their children before public schools were opened (Lyda).  By 1850, Linton Township had 50 blacks; by 1870, that number had grown to 102.  Today a cemetery is all that remains of the Underwood Settlement."

properties.Name: Vallonia
properties.Summary: Seeing information about Native American history, nothing else from listed source. Town does exist but no history on it and white population no, it seems

properties.Name: Weaver
properties.Summary: Large population on +3k acres during its hayday for the later half of the 19th century. Grant County, 40.46532, -85.72915 listed on GeoHack/Wiki. Founded by freed blacks and escaped slaves and later named after Weaver family (previously "Crossroads". Heavily researced but listed sources lead to invalid links sometimes. Weaver cemetery still exists, unclear which church (there were multiple; AME church, Hills Chapel, Baptist). And a school, stores, an a racetrack according to one source. They still meat annually. Lynching warning: some articles/books have photos.

properties.Name: Guinea Bottom
properties.Summary: Guinea Bottom appears to have been a settlement area for free Black people who were still tied to their owners as indentured laborers. Ben and Ben and Venus McGee were freed by George Rogers Clark in 1802, however at least Ben McGee was required to labor as an indentured servent to Clark for another 30 years. Indentured people could also be bought and sold. The historic site of Clark's house and a replica of slave cabin was burned down in May 2021.

properties.Name: Buxton
properties.Summary: Coalmining ghost town, historic designation 1983. Originally established when a coal mining company needed black workers and made a town for them. First source claims: "In the 1905 census, the town boasted 2,700 African American and 1,991 whites." Also had black professionals, social programs, and allegedly good race relations with the white/Swedish miners. Lots of info and photos in the Iowa Culture source, and interesting class dynamics have been noted

properties.Name: Muchakinock
properties.Summary: Coal mining camp, this time, in Mahaska County. Also not segregated like Buxton. Brought in ~70 black miners from VA to break a strike. "BY THE LATE 1880s, Muchakinock had become the state�s largest unincorporated coal mining community, with a population of between 1,500 and 1,800 inhabitants in 1887. " Closely related to Buxton, double check

properties.Name: Westfield Township
properties.Summary: Iowa has a low black population overall, especially then. Small family settlements. "In the 1850s a small group of free African Americans migrated from Kankakee, Illinois," Need more research to see if this counts.

properties.Name: Daniel Votaw Colony
properties.Summary: Migrated from Texas led by a freed slave named Paul Davis who purchased then parceled land to 25 families. 1895, flood ruined the community, decline by early 1900s. Exoduster community. One man as of 2010 was trying to reevive interest in DVC.

properties.Name: Dunlap Colony
properties.Summary: Cemetery is on National Register of Historic Places. Founded by Joseph Dunlap. In later years, Benjamin "Pap" Singleton brought more exodusters to the area. Built churches and an academy. Expanded rapidly in the early 1900s, stores, businesses. Survived well into the late 20th century. Many buildings still stand but first source says that the last black resident died in the 1900s. Has a wiki page.

properties.Name: Hoggs Town
properties.Summary: Might be Hoggstown. Coords take me to "Lawrence Cultural District" but place seems white. Wyandotte County, allegedly in Kansas City. I can't find this place? Mentioned once in SoA source. Orange font denotes mention only here, little additional evidence otherwise

properties.Name: Juniper Town
properties.Summary: Only seeing references to it, no sources beyond saying it existed.

properties.Name: Little Coney Colony
properties.Summary: Chautauqua County, most references are that it existed except listed. I'm getting the sense that these Pap Singleton Colonies were real but just have little info. It seems that some failed before they could be officially established. Page 52 of (Blake 1928) source states 56 families lived there and that it began in 1881 and was supported by the Kansas Freedman's Relief Association.

properties.Name: Mississippi Town
properties.Summary: "Mississippi Town was located near Kansas City. It was settled in 1887 and continued to exist until 1927. Today, it has been integrated into Kansas City." (NPS Source). Coords aren't in the official lines of KS according to Google maps, but in the vicinity.

properties.Name: Morton City
properties.Summary: Some descendants alive who researched their family history. SW of Nicodemus in Hodgeman County. Some remnants remain (looks like a rubble structure). Potential cemetery.Town short lived, resients couldn't make a living and sold their land.

properties.Name: Mudtown
properties.Summary: Black district of Topeka. KSHS source says its north of Topeka but coords take us to a field in western central area. "Black communities also formed within cities like Topeka and Kansas City.  Tennessee Town, Mudtown, Jordan Town, Mississippi Town, and Rattlebone Hollow, the names given to these communities, often reflected the growing prejudice against these newcomers."

properties.Name: Nicodemus
properties.Summary: Historic designation. Wiki page. Graham County. Promoted by Pap Singleton as AAs were expanding west after the Homestead Act. Six AAs started a company here in 1877 and bolstered a farming community. Decline by 1890 but descendants still meet. Historic site has five buildings total. "The oldest and only remaining Black settlement west of the Mississippi River." According to NPS source. Heavily researched place.

properties.Name: Quindaro
properties.Summary: Underground railroad affiiliated and pre-Kansas statehood! Historic designation and wiki page. Not there but allegedly still a neighborhood with this name. Old Quindaro Cemetery was established in 1853 and "is the oldest in the state." Started by abolitionists. Named after the daughter of a chief (Canadian Wyandot). Native American ties. Additional research needed to see if it was made for or by black people-- some sources don't mention African Americans at all. Whole townsite was incorporated into Kansas City.

properties.Name: Rattlebone Hollow
properties.Summary: May have originally began as a German migrant enclave in Kansas City then turned black. Same with Juniper. "...he remaining group built homes along Jersey Creek in a settlement called "Rattlebone Hollow" (pg 24, Blake source). Community was absorbed into KS, does that count?

properties.Name: Redmonsville
properties.Summary: Black enclave in north Topeka.

properties.Name: Ritchie's Addition (The Bottoms)
properties.Summary: Another black district in Topeka. Potentially historic. Do these count as "towns?" Otherwise we'd have to include every black enclave in every urban center too. Coords are northeast of Historic Ritchie House which was an underground railroad stop. Founder was not black, but an abolitionist. Site of Brown v Board's Monroe school.

properties.Name: Singleton Colony
properties.Summary: Founded by Benjamin "Pap" Singleton in Cherokee County "north of Baxter Springs." Seems like it declined relatively quickly and Singleton made new colonies like Dunlap. Not clear if this was the same colony as Dunlap.

properties.Name: Summit Township
properties.Summary: According to source "a small colony was formed in Saline County in 1879 when... part of a caravan of 500 black bound for Nicodeemeus separated from the caravan and colonized on three sections in Summit town near the Swedish colony of Falun" (20-21).Coords are a few miles SE of a Falun area. There is still a Summit Township but unclear if it is related. One of the only towns not attached to a larger town due to urban centers drawing employment

properties.Name: Tennessee Town
properties.Summary: "Bounded by Buchanan and Washburn streets, "Tennessee Town" was primarily settled by blacks from 1879 to 1881. " (Mudtown source). Home of the Coloured Women's Clubhouse which is on the National Register. In the heart of Topeka.Hosted four churches and the first black kindergarden west of the Mississippi (Tennessee Town History Source). This town lasted much longer than the others but has declined greatly in the 1980s.

properties.Name: Wabaunsee Colony
properties.Summary: Also estalished by the Freedman�s Relief Association, in northern Topeka (KSHS source). The county (and probably the town) was a stop on the Underground Railroad.

properties.Name: Estill's Station
properties.Summary: Named after Captain James Estill (Estil County namesake) and his enslaved servant Monk Estill who was registered as the first freed black person in Kentucky. Fun fact: Monk had 3 wives and 30 kids... Town is currently all white, doesn't seem like it was ever a black town, just a significat black historical figure who saved a white town.

properties.Name: Hall
properties.Summary: Unknown. Coords end up in Knott County, and an oral history collection is in another. No mention of Hall (beyond one slave name) in source

properties.Name: Corbin
properties.Summary: Potential black enclave. 200 blacks were driven out during a race riot in 1919, but unclear if it was considered a black town at any point. Seems unlikely.

properties.Name: Berrytown
properties.Summary: East Jefferson County, five acres purchased by former slave Alfred Berry who let families build on it. Area supplies workers to wealthy nearby white neigborhood. A historic cemetery mentioned there. Decline in the 1960s.Should be noted that Chickasaw Park existed nearby but was only a black park. Coords lead to a marker. Wiki.

properties.Name: Griffeytown
properties.Summary: Started when a freedman named Dan Griffith moved to Old Harrod�s Creek Road in the 19th century. Wiki. Historical Marker.

properties.Name: Petersburg (Newburg)
properties.Summary: Once called Petersburg, Newburg was founded by Eliza Curtis Hundley Tevis, a freed black woman who bought land during the antebellum period prior to the Civil War . Wiki.

properties.Name: Harrods Creek
properties.Summary: Relatively affluent neighborhood in Louisville developed by James T. Taylor with some historic houses like the Merriweather House. Near the town of Prospect, which is/was also recognized in some sources as a black town. Wiki.

properties.Name: Covington
properties.Summary: Covington was an essential free Black, freedmen, and escaped slave settlement prior to the Civil War. Covington had the highest population of Black people and was a close destination for runaways from due to its location at the confluence of the Ohio River and near Cincinnati, OH (Lucas, 2003).

properties.Name: Fazendeville
properties.Summary: Fazendeville was a Black town founded where the Battle of New Orleans was fought on the east side of the Mississippi River in the lower ninth ward/St. Bernard parish of New Orleans (present-day Chalmette neighborhood). The settlement was started by Jean Pierre Fazende who subdivided land he inherited after the Civil War and sold parcels to emancipated Black people. The community was razed in 1964 to expand the National Monument commemorating the battle. The location points to the Chalmette monument.

properties.Name: Bobtown
properties.Summary: "In 1898, an African American man named Robert Celestin and his father-in-law Bob Greasy purchased a large portion of a plantation in Terrebonne Parish and established a village they named Bobtown" (115). Notable cemetery and characterized as a safe haven.

properties.Name: Grambling
properties.Summary: First all-Black municipality in Louisiana to be incorporated then declared a city in 1993. Home of Grambling State University. Still majority black till this day! The Historic Lincoln Parish District has nearly 30 sites listed.

properties.Name: Mossville
properties.Summary: Founded by Jack Moss, an ex-slave, in 1790. The town was for formerly enslaved people. Wiki. Contemporary history entangled with a pollution controversy that is understood to have poisoned residents.

properties.Name: St. Maurice
properties.Summary: Possibly founded in 1760s as a plantation community but unclear. Potentially early 1820s-1830s. Included the St. Maurice Plantation what was on the National Register until 2019 when it was removed. Still vastly majority black according to City Data. Attached to the Prothro Mansion which had slaves. Seems that it was primarily poor African Americans and European immigrants in the beginning. Most likely named after St. Maurice who was a heroic black-descended (blackamoor) Christian figure.

properties.Name: Treme
properties.Summary: Neighborhood in New Orleans (do these count?) that was mixed black and creole cultures that sprung from the original Morand Plantation. Also called "Back of Town" and "Faubourg Trem�." The New Orleans African American Museum is located here along with the St. Augustine Church which is recognized as the oldest African-American Catholic parish in the country. It has been referred to as the oldest black neighborhood in the US too. It is still referred to as having a very rich and lively culture.  Wiki.

properties.Name: Washington
properties.Summary: Third oldest community in LA. Site of violence, Opelousas massacre nearby. Currently only around half Black but seemed to have a larger population during its early period. Historic sites like the Arlington Plantation House that is nationally registered. Wiki.  Check Lower 9th ward for next session,

properties.Name: Lower Ninth Ward
properties.Summary: I'm not sure if this technically counts as a "Black Town" but this community might prove to be a testiment to AA resiliency. Katrina destruction in 2005. Lincoln Beach nearby, Black beach. More research can be done if this counts as a BT. 1852 it was declared a voting district.

properties.Name: Bailey Island
properties.Summary: Founded by a possibly emancipated person named Black Will. Sources mostly repeat what the Wikipedia page says: "The first settler of the island was William Black, son of Black Will who was a freed slave from Kittery, Maine. William sold the land his father had left him in the Upper Parish of Kittery and settled permanently on Bailey's Island. Because of this, the island became known as Will's Island." Some scandal at the time too, as it is said that Black Will Jr. was the product of an interracial affair.

properties.Name: Harbor Island
properties.Summary: Likely traces back to an emancipated man on Malaga Island�s named Benjamin Darling who acquired what is now Harbor Island in Phippsburg. The descendants settled on serveral surrounding islands over time. I think these two should be condensed into the Harbor Island/Malaga Island cluster.

properties.Name: Malaga Island
properties.Summary: Very close proximity to Harbor Island in Phippsburg. Seems to be the same community, just on two different islands as the Darling descendants spread out. Mixed raced community and, according to sources, was less racially prejudiced during the islands early decades.Tragic story of eugenics movement affected the population there in the early 20th century, as the black population was seen as a stain on Maine's reputation. Evicted in 1912. Museum source says that "Malagite" was used as a slur.

properties.Name: Bangor
properties.Summary: Newly added but may only be a black part of town. Aside from Portland which had nearly 300 black residents near the turn of the 20th century, Bangor had the next largest population.Originally a substantial lumber city for much of its history that also attracted black Canadians. Incorporated as a a town in 1791 and as a city in 1834. City exists today but most likely not the original community.

properties.Name: Brownsville
properties.Summary: Brownsville was a Black community in Frostburg, MD that existed from the 1860s-1950s. It was started in 1866 when Tamar Brown purchased a lot in the area. Elizabeth Jackson is also credited as being an early founder and her lot neighbored Brown's. Frostburg State University exists where the town once was located. The expansion of the university beginning in the 1920s resulted in the displacement and dispossession of Brownsville communities. Brownsville is an unincorporated community and census designated place. The location is set to Dickerson AME Church which seems to be one of the last remaining buildings from the community that was there.

properties.Name: Glenarden
properties.Summary: Located in Prince George's County, the community was deleloped in 1919 after it was purchased by William R. Smith. The town is still predominantly African American today.

properties.Name: Highland Beach
properties.Summary: An elite black beach community  south of Annapolis along the Chesapeake Bay. According to the Highland Beach communtity website, it was established after "...Major Charles Douglass, youngest son of Frederick Douglass, and Charles� wife Laura, were turned away from a restaurant at the Bay Ridge Resort and Amusement Park because of their race" in 1892. A year later they established this resort community. Today it remains a private community for Highland's residents.

properties.Name: Hill Settlement (Hill Community)
properties.Summary: Also called the Hill Community. Another runner for the oldest free black community in the US, Hill Settlement is located in Easton Maryland. The community has many old and historic buildings still in existance. Archaeological finds also populate the knowledge about the community alongside descendants who continue to live there.

properties.Name: North Brentwood
properties.Summary: North Brentwood was the first African American town to be incorporated into Prince George's county, which is the wealthiest black county in the United States. It was established in 1817 but populated by black veterans in 1887. Hosts a North Brentwood Historic District which has over a dozen historic structures.   Wiki.

properties.Name: Sugarland
properties.Summary: Developed by freed slaves in Montogomery County who bought tracts of land near one another during the later half of the 19th century. It is an "autonomous Black township" that boasted a church, school, post office, and store that kept it self-sustaining. Named for the sugar maples that dotted the surrounding landscape.

properties.Name: Unionville
properties.Summary: Unionville is in Talbot County on Maryland's Eastern Shore that was established by 18 African American war veterans. The land was offered to them by a Quaker couple. Wiki.

properties.Name: Lakeland
properties.Summary: Lakeland was originally platted in 1890 for whites but settled by African Americans who lived or worked in the nearby University of Maryland by 1903. It had a few schools and has two still-standing churches, First Baptist Church (1891) and Embry African Methodist Episcopal Church (1903). It is still a community but is being highly gentrified with university housing.

properties.Name: Eagle Harbor
properties.Summary: Eagle Harbor is a shoreside community tucked along the Patuxent River. It was started in 1925 and the community still meets annually for Eagle Harbor Day. Trueman Point was given historic designation by the Maryland-National Capital Park & Planning Commission. Wiki.

properties.Name: Bowie
properties.Summary: One of the wealthiest African American communities in the United States. Currently about half Black but was not started by an African American person or group. One black historic site is the Don S. S. Goodloe House. More research needed to see if there are specific black enclaves within Bowie such as Mitchellville. Wiki.

properties.Name: San Domingo
properties.Summary: San Domingo is an unincorporated free Black Town started by John Brown in northwestern Wicomico County between 1810-1820. Location points to San Domingo School Community & Cultural Center in Sharptown.

properties.Name: Parting Ways
properties.Summary: Also called "New Guinea", this was a freedman community that was established by four African-American Revolutionary War veterans named PlatoTurner, Cato Howe, Prince Goodwin, and Quamony Quash. The Parting Ways Archeological District was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1979. The cemetery is still present and it borders Plymouth.

properties.Name: Idlewild
properties.Summary: Idlewild was a black resort town established in 1912 but was not popular until 1915. It was originally advertised by white land developers to African Americans. This "Black Eden" was a thriving community during its day, with around 300 businsses at its peak and vibrant nightlife that attracted elite blacks like Madam CJ Walker, W.E.B. Dubois and more. It declined in the 1960s but was added to the National Register as a Historic District in. Wiki.

properties.Name: Marlborough
properties.Summary: Southwest of Idlewood and comes up alongside Idlewood searches. It was added to the NRHP in 1972. Not seeing anything about African Americans, only about its significance as a cement industry location. There is an adjacent Baldwin that could be promising.

properties.Name: Ramptown
properties.Summary: Ramptown was established by escaped enslaved persons with the help of Quakers. The community had a school and church but did not seem to have an established boundary, as the approximately two dozen cabins seemed to be scattered, according to archaeologists. It was named after the wild onions called "ramps" that grew nearby. Underground Railroad affiliated. One source says it was "...the final stop on the Underground Railroad for many African Americans who fled slavery from the 1830s to 1860s" (WMU).

properties.Name: Davis Bend (Davis Island)
properties.Summary: This post-Civil War community was named after the plantation owner Joseph Emory Davis who created the "model cooperative slave community" on Hurricane Plantation. He owned 350 slaves and they remained on the property as a community until the 1880s. More important that an enslaver, Davis worked with freedman Benjamin T. Montgomery who was a notable inventor during the time. Wiki.

properties.Name: Expose
properties.Summary: Not seeing anything beyond just the mentioning of it in the two listed sources

properties.Name: Mound Bayou
properties.Summary: Mound Bayou is a still-existing, still all-black community that migrated from Davis Bend. It is said that the migration was led by Isaiah Montgomery. It had churches, stores and other buildings that made it self-sustaining until the 1960s when it started to decline.  Wiki.

properties.Name: Renova
properties.Summary: A majority black community that was most likely established by or around the 20th century. Not much information available. Wiki.

properties.Name: Winstonville
properties.Summary: Winstonville is a small majority-black community that is near Mount Bayou. Not much information available. Wiki.

properties.Name: Kinloch
properties.Summary: Kinloch is the oldest incorporated African-American community in Missouri. Many families were displaced in 1980 when the St. Louis airport bought land and sought to expand the runway into Kinloch. The airport never did expand.

properties.Name: Meacham Park
properties.Summary: In 1892 a real estate speculator bought land in the area and started selling plots of land to both Black people and white people for relatively cheap. The area became a predominately Black settlement and the small white population fled especially during the 1950s-60s. ("By 1950 of the over 1300 residents less than 300 where white�by the mid 1960�s just 13 white residents remained."). The area remained an unincorporated area of St. Louis county until in 1958 a nonresidential portion of the town was annexed by Kirkwood (controversial because they obviously did this to exclude Black residents) and in 1992 the remaining area was annexed.

properties.Name: North Webster Groves
properties.Summary: In 1866 William Porter bought land in north Webster which he subdivided into lots to be purchased by freedmen to build their homes (Morris & Nagel, 19993, p. 4). "Porter's subdivision ran from Pacific Avenue down the steep side of the hill through the woods to Shady Creek and Shady Avenue." (p.4). Black families went on to settle in Porter's subdivision and most found work in/for white families homes in Webster Groves. The city of Webster was incorporated in 1896 and Webster Groves has a historical society. Missouri State archives has a digital collection on African Americans in Northeast Missouri.

properties.Name: Pennytown
properties.Summary: "In 1871, Joe Penny, a freedman from Kentucky, paid $160 for eight acres of land in Saline County, Missouri, just south of Marshall. This was the first of eleven purchases Penny and other black families in the area made during the next eight years. By 1879, these eleven land acquisitions, each averaging six and one-half acres, constituted the sixty four acres known as Pennytown, the largest of Saline County�s historic black hamlets." (pennytownchurch.org/history)

properties.Name: Pinhook
properties.Summary: Founded by Black sharecoppers in the 1920s according to article by Schuessler (2014)

properties.Name: DeWitty
properties.Summary: "DeWitty was a homestead colony in Cherry County, Nebraska located 10 miles northwest of Brownlee. The community began forming in 1904 with the Kinkaid Act. This act expanded the Homestead Act allowing individuals to claim 640 acres of land in Nebraska's sand hills." (NPS.gov) Town was named after Miles H. DeWitty who established and ran the first post office there. Families who moved here were connected to the Black town of Empire, Wyoming.

properties.Name: Overton
properties.Summary: Black homesteaders (from USA and majority from Canada) claimed lands under the Homestead Act and later under the Kincaid Act. This was the earliest of the Black homesteading communities that would develop in Nebraska and Wyoming.

properties.Name: Coit Mountain
properties.Summary: A small community of free (escaped slaves) Black farmers developed around Coit Mountain (in Newport, New Hampshire) in the late 18th century. The area is named after Vance Coit (also known as Richard) who moved to the area between 1775-1790, established a home near the mountain peak. Coit had left the are by 1803.

properties.Name: Adat Beyt Mosheh
properties.Summary: Black orthodox Jewish community that was started in the 1960s. The congregation was founded by Rabbi Abel Respes in the 1950s (around 1951). In search of a better way of life, the congregation put together their resources to buy land near Hammonton, NJ.

properties.Name: Timbuctoo
properties.Summary: Established in 1826 by four Black men (former slaves) who purchased land from Quakers in the area.

properties.Name: Small Gloucester (Dutchtown)
properties.Summary: Small Gloucester was a free Black community established during the early ninteenth century. Like other NJ Black Towns, Small Gloucester was established near Quaker abolitionist strongholds in NJ. It was an important town along the Underground Railroad. Coordinates direct to Mt. Zion Church which was built in 1834.

properties.Name: Cootstown
properties.Summary: Cootstown was a free Black community near Swedesboro (in Woolwhich township). Coordinates direct to Woolwhich township. This town should not be confused with the African burial grounds at Cookstown.

properties.Name: Saddlertown
properties.Summary: Joshua Saddler, an escaped slave, purchased 5 acres of land in Haddon Township on May 3, 1842. coordinates direct to Saddler's Woods Conservation Association

properties.Name: Gouldtown
properties.Summary: Gouldtown is referred to as the first free Black community in the US. Like other NJ Black Towns, Gouldtown was established in a Quaker/abolitionist region. 1839 marriage to a white woman was a huge scandal.

properties.Name: Swedesboro
properties.Summary: Unclear if this was a Black town in and of itself, or just a town in the area where many NJ Black Towns were located.

properties.Name: Morris Beach
properties.Summary: Morris Beach was a community established in Egg Harbor Township, NJ in1938 by Jennie Morris (who was a mortician in Philadelphia). The community consisted of 23 houses and was intended to be a vacation/resort community for Black middle class professionals from Philly.

properties.Name: Port Republic
properties.Summary: Port Republic was another mid-nineteenth century Black town in NJ. A cemetery contains graves for 6 Black Civil War veterans who were believed to be among the towns leadership. At least a dozen families were still living in the area in 1874, but by 1910 all were gone.

properties.Name: Newtonville
properties.Summary: Newtonville was one of many Black places included in Wendell A. White's Small Towns, Black Lives project.

properties.Name: Elsmere
properties.Summary: Pre-Civil War Black community also known as "80 Acres" farmland in Glassboro, NJ

properties.Name: Chesilhurst
properties.Summary: A number of sources briefly make reference to Chesilhurst as a site of a significant Black community. According to the 2010 census the population is majority Black (46%).

properties.Name: Lawnside
properties.Summary: First known as "Free Hill", "Free Haven" and "Snow Hill", Lawnside is located in Camden County, NJ (9 miles from Philadelphia) and is the only incorporated independent Black town in the state. Black people established homes there due to nearby Quaker abolitionists allies that rallied against the use of slave labor in the county's industrial and agricultural businesses during the 18th century. Quakers also hepled to prevent the kidnapping and re-enslavement of free/escaped slaves in the area. Black self-governance of the town began around 1797 with the establishment of the Methodist meetings and when in 1811 Bishop Richard Allen established the first AME church there. The town incorporated under the name Lawnside in 1926.

properties.Name: Marshalltown
properties.Summary: Marshalltown is was a "free Black community" or "free-Black settlement" located in Salem County, NJ during the 19th century. Its name is derived from Thomas Marshall, a free Black man who bought land around 1834 and subdivided into plots and went on to house 30 families/homes, a few churches, and other institutions of interest. The closing of Marshalltown school in 1951 appears to mark the decline of what was an independent Black community.

properties.Name: Othello
properties.Summary: Othello was one of a few free Black towns that developed following the 1804 (Gradual) Emancipation Act in New Jersey.

properties.Name: Springtown
properties.Summary: "Located in the northern end of Greenwhich Township, Springtown was established around 1800 by slaves who had been manumitted or who had escaped from bondage in Deleware, Maryland or states further south." (Wright, 1988, p. 39)

properties.Name: Whitesboro
properties.Summary: Whitesboro was an independent Black town established in 1902 when Black people who were fed up with facing racist violence/exclusion in Cape May County, New Jersey. Reverend J.W. Fishburn and four other members of Cape May City�s AME Zion Church founded the Equitable Industrial Association and purchased 2,000 acres of land for $14,000 in Whitesboro. The town derives its name from George White, one of the investors who purchased the land. The town still exists and is known as Whitesboro-Burleigh.

properties.Name: Blackdom
properties.Summary: A small independent settlement of Black homesteaders was started in the early 1900s by Francis Marion Boyer who was fleeing racist/KKK violence. By 1908 the population was 300, the town had a newspaper, church, and businesses. The town fell apart in the 1920s due to crop failures. The National Postal Museum has the postal book from Blackdom from 1912-1919.

properties.Name: Dora
properties.Summary: Several sources make references to post-Civil War Black towns/ Black settlement in Dora, NM. More details are needed.

properties.Name: Las Cruces
properties.Summary: Several sources make references to post-Civil War Black towns/ Black settlement in Las Cruces, NM. More details are needed.

properties.Name: Vado
properties.Summary: Vado was a Black Town in Dona Ana County, NM. It was also started by Francis Marion Boyner and those who founded Blackdom and recruited many other Black southerners to the area.

properties.Name: Guinea Town (New Guinea)
properties.Summary: Guinea Town (or New Guinea) was a Black town in the Hudson Valley that existed during the 1790-1860s. Eliakim Levi and Primus Martin were two leaders within the Black community. The town was an important stop along the Underground Railroad for escaped slaves that migrated to Nova Scotia. Coordinates are at Hacket Hill Park, what is now an adventure camp was once the area where the settlement was.

properties.Name: Eastville, Sag Harbor
properties.Summary: Not sure that this is a Black Town. Eastville was a multi-racial and ethnic community comprised of Black, Native American, and ethnic white populations. The Black history centers around the construction of St. David AME Church in 1839 and its preservation as a historical and cultural landmark. It may also have been an important site of the Underground Railroad network.

properties.Name: Five Points District
properties.Summary: The Black community that later became known as 'Five Points District' is regarded as NY's first free Black settlement. Between 1810-1820 a number of free Black people were living as in-home laborers in white Manhattan homes. Black churches established in the area before 1810 (Abyssinia Church - 1808). By 1810 the majority of Black residents in Manhattan lived near the Fresh Water Pond. By the 1840s-1850s the area located on on the five-cornered intersection of what were then Anthony, Cross, Orange and Little Water streets, called Five Points, became infamously known as a racially mixed slum/ red light district. The Black community was driven out in 1863 due to draft riots. Archaeological excavations during the 1990s in lower Manhattan unearthed this earlier history.

properties.Name: Sandy Ground
properties.Summary: One of the earliest free Black settlements in the US. In 1828 Captain John Jackson was the first Black man to purchase land on Staten Island. The community was also known as Harrisville and Little Africa before being called Sandy Ground due to the soil condition. A 1964 fire destroyed most buildings.

properties.Name: York Hill
properties.Summary: York Hill was a Black community in NYC that was grazed during the 1830s to build a receiving reservoir for the Croton Aqueduct (York Hill Receiving Reservoir, later known as Lower Reservoir). William A. Mathews owned 5 acres in York Hill. Mathews later became Deacon of the African Union Methodist Church of Seneca Village. Members of the York Hill community moved to nearby Seneca Village which was later grazed to build Central Park.

properties.Name: Seneca Village
properties.Summary: Seneca Village was a historic Black settlement in Manhattan (between 81st and 89th Streets and Seventh and Eighth Avenue) from 1825-1857. The community was grazed to create Central Park.

properties.Name: Weeksville
properties.Summary: Located in what is now Bedford-Stuyvesant and Crown Heights neighborhoods of Brooklyn, NY was an antebellum free Black community called Weeksville. The town was named after John Weeks, a former slave, who purchased 2 plots of land in 1838 . Weeks had purchased the land from another former slave and Black abolitionist, Henry C. Thompson, who sold land to free Black people migrating to the area. Thompson had originally purchased 32 lots from John Lefferets during a period of white flight (White Panic of 1837).

properties.Name: Beech Bottom
properties.Summary: A small Black community formed in the lowlands of northwest North Carolina (southern Appalachia). Black people were brought to the area as slaves in the early to mid-1800s. Local history by longterm residents states that Hampton Jackson founded the community as a multi-ethnic community in 1870. The population declined starting in the 1940s as residents migrated for jobs elsewhere.

properties.Name: Bethania
properties.Summary: Within a Moravian town in Forsyth County known for its European agriculture plan sat a Black Freedmen's Community along Bethania-Rural Hall Road. In the 1760s thousands of Black slaves were brought to the area for construction and agricultural labor. Following emancipation white residents built separate educational and religious buildings for newly free Black residents. In 1875 Black minister, A.T. Goslen, formed the AME church in Bethania. Black residents in Bethania moved toward Rural Hall Road to achieve greater autonomy from their former Moravian owners. In 1881 Pierce Alspaugh and his wife Lydia Beck purchased acreage to start their own family farm near Wesley Lash, another Black farmer. In 2006 the town threatened to demolish structures like the Alspaugh house and other architectural elements of the Freedmen's Community. Location points to 1840 Bethania Rural Hall Rd where Alspaugh-Shouse house was.

properties.Name: Hayti
properties.Summary: Hayti was established by emancipated Black people in Durham, NC following the Civil War. In 1868 Edian Markham established an AME church, Union Bethel AME which was later renamed St. Joseph Church. The community grew to include a number of Black business such as the North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance co. During the 1960s urban renewal period Hayti was targeted for complete decimation. Over 4,000 families and 500 buildings were displaced by urban renewal and the Durham freeway.

properties.Name: James City
properties.Summary: James City was a Black community formed by Horace James in 1862 near the Trent River. James joined the Freedman's Bureau and help settle a campsite there with escaped slaves in 1863. Following the Civil War in 1867 the Union expropriated the land to its former owner James Bryan. Bryan attempted to force Black residents to work on the land as low wage sharecroppers or to pay exorbitant rents. The residents opposed by all means, and even fundraised to buy the land from Bryant, however they were always struck down by the state. The town went from 3000 residents to just 700 by 1893.

properties.Name: Freedmen of Roanoke Island (Little California)
properties.Summary: Freemen Colony of Roanoke Island was formed by fugitive slaves during the Civil War era. This community was called a "contraband camp" - where escapees who remained in the South were protected from their former owners. The camp was organized by the Freedmen's Bureau under the leadership of Elizabeth James. In April 1863 Rev. Horace James was appointed superintendent of the 2,700 Black residents (300 families) of the island.

properties.Name: Navassa (Bluff Hill)
properties.Summary: Navassa was a small town created by the construction of railroad tracks to connect Wilmington to Charlotte, NC in 1867. The area was called "Bluff Hill" because of a large cliff-like land mass that separated the town from Wilmington. In 1869 the Navassa Guano factory was built there to process guano deposits from a small island off the coast of Jamaica where the town gets its name. In 1885 a fertilizer factory was built in the town. It seems like town developed as an industrial town for Gullah peoples who left the plantations after the civil war.
