The town remains majority Black (nearly 90% of the population). The town was incorporated in 1977 and has been the site of large luxury redevelopment in recent years.

properties.Name: Princeville (Freedom Hill)
properties.Summary: Princeville was chartered as Freedom Hill in 1865 by newly freed Black community members. The town was incorporated in 1885 by the state General Assembly. The town was renamed Princeville in 1905 to honor Tuner Prince for his leadership in the community, especially after a devastating flood.

properties.Name: Sedalia
properties.Summary: It is unclear when this town was first established (it was likely a post-Civil war development like other nearby towns). The Bethany Church and Bethany Still Institute were established in 1870. In 1902 Charlotte Hawkins moved to Sedalia and established the Palmer Memorial Institute and taught thousands of rural Black children. The institute became the first historic place in the state recognized for Black history. Sedalia still has the highest percentage of Black residents in the state (over 90% Black).

properties.Name: Soul City
properties.Summary: In 1969 Floyd McKissik sought to create a "black-built" town in Warren County, NC that was a Black capitalist utopian vision for Black social, political, and economic progress. McKissick had ambitious plans for jobs and industry in the town and secured a large HUD model city grant and aimed to build. The town faced numerous administrative, financial, and political challenges and only employed about 150 people by 1980.

properties.Name: Midway
properties.Summary: Midway is one a several unincorporated Black towns/communities in Moore County, NC. The town is surrounded by Aberdeen and Southern Pines and has sought annexation by Aberdeen. The Midway Community Association formed in the 1960s.

properties.Name: Monroetown (Monroe Town)
properties.Summary: Monroetown is one of two unincorporated predominately Black towns/communities bordered by Pinehurst (a white town). The town is surrounded by a golf course. Pinehurst attempted to annex Monroetown however the community resisted.

properties.Name: Lost City
properties.Summary: Lost City is an all Black unincorporated small town surrounded by the incorporated white town of Southern Pines.

properties.Name: Taylortown (or Taylor Town, also Old Settlement)
properties.Summary: Taylortown was established in the early 1900s by Demus Taylor. The town provided the major workforce to the nearby white town of Pinehurst. Taylortown was incorporated in 1987.

properties.Name: Jackson Hamlet
properties.Summary: Jackson Hamlet is an unincorporated Black town surrounded by nearby white town of Pinehurst.

properties.Name: Waynor Road
properties.Summary: Waynor Road is a small unincorporated Black town surrounded by Southern Pines and Carthage.

properties.Name: Pinetops
properties.Summary: Pinetops is a historic Black community in Edgecombe, NC. Pinetops is said to have been incorporated as a train station on the Eastern Carolina railway in 1903. The Vinedale plantation was established in 1855 by John A. Vine (later owned by his daughter Linda Vines Cobb) which might be why the town has a large Black population.

properties.Name: Green Level Historic District
properties.Summary: Green Level is near Cary in  Wake County, NC. Green Level Baptist Church is one of a few buildings that make up the historic district.

properties.Name: Evans Road
properties.Summary: Along Evans Road in Cary was a Black "enclave" started by Clyde Evans (1893-1985) when he purchased 200 acres through a foreclosure sale. Evans subdivided the property and sold lots to other Black people, creating an area that was known as Evans Estates subdivision. Cary Christian Church built at church on a 1-acre lot that was donated by Evans in 1966. Location points to West Cary Middle School.

properties.Name: Historic West End (Charlotte)
properties.Summary: The Historic West End is comprised of a number of Black communities (Brooklyn, Cherry, Greenville, Biddleville etc.) developed around the HBCU Johnson C. Smith University (formerly Biddle Institute) in Charlotte.

properties.Name: African American West End (Watkins Street)
properties.Summary: African American West End was a Black community in Winston Salem along Watkins Street that was demolished under urban renewal to create a path for the I-40 freeway and later in 2007 to build the BB&T (Truist) baseball park.

properties.Name: West End (Mebane)
properties.Summary: West End is an unincorporated area just outside of Mebane (Alamance County) established by former slaves. Since the 1990s the community fought against a freeway/interstate bypass that would have razed the town. Location points to St. Luke's Church.

properties.Name: White Level
properties.Summary: White Level (like Mebane's West End) is an unincorporated Black community near Mebane. Residents of White Level asked to be annexed by Mebane in 1997 due to lack of sewage infrastructure.

properties.Name: Buckhorn/ Perry Hill
properties.Summary: Buckhorn/Perry Hill are unincorporated Black communities east of Mebane, NC. Location points to Mount Moriah Missionary Baptist church.

properties.Name: Silver City
properties.Summary: Silver City is an unincorporated Black community that is adjacent to and excluded from the city of Raeford in Hoke County, NC. Silver City is a census designated place.

properties.Name: Grand Forks / Lithia
properties.Summary: In 1884 William T. Montgomery purchased 1,020 acres of land. He named the town Lithia after his mother. During the 1890s after North Dakota became a state many Black soldiers were stationed at Fort Buford. In 1895 the military post was abandoned. By 1910 Black homesteaders owned 22 farms throughout the state.

properties.Name: Port Royal (Canada)
properties.Summary: A community of Black "loyalists" (those who supported the British Empire in the Revolutionary War) established a community in Port Royal, a place that is now called Annapolis Royal.

properties.Name: Carthagena
properties.Summary: A Black farming community that was established in 1835 by a white Quaker abolitionist, Agustus Wattles, who "led" 15 Black families to Carthagena as they were fleeing racial terror in Western Ohio. It is said that a Virginia slave owner, John Randolph, had emanicipated 383 slaves in his will and promised them land in Carthagena. When the hundreds of formerly enslaved moved to the area white riots ensued. There is a large cemetery in the area that was desecrated in more recent years.

properties.Name: Augusta
properties.Summary: Augusta is one of a number of free Black communities established in Ohio prior to the Civil War. Augusta was an area of cotton plantations. By 1787 a number of free Black peoples established a Baptist church, Springfield Baptist Church. After the Civil War more freedmen moved to the area and established communities now regarded as historic districts such as, Pinch Gulf, Laney-Walker, Bethlehem, and Sand Hills.

properties.Name: Berlin Crossroads
properties.Summary: Berlin Crossroads was established by Jemima and Thomas Woodson who purchased land between 1829-1830 (LaRoche, 2014, p. 79). The free Black agricultural town was an integral part of the Underground Railroad and the abolitionist movement.

properties.Name: Black Fort
properties.Summary: Black Fort Settlement was an important community for free and runaway slaves during the 1800s to early 1900s. By 1818 the Black community had established a church.

properties.Name: Fitchville
properties.Summary: Fitchville appears to have been a primary stop along the Underground Railroad in Huron County, OH. Unclear whether this was a Black Town/ free Black community. Seeley Palmer house may have been a prominent white abolitionist home.

properties.Name: Gallipolis
properties.Summary: Gallipolis was an integral part of the Underground Railroad. In 1818 several free Black people established a community, including an African Methodist Episcopal Chapel (Barbara and John Gee; William and Eliza Napper; Leah Stewart; Nancy Belt; John Givens and Lorian Givens). The church was dedicated and renamed for John Gee in the 1880s. Gee was a carpenter and land owner who built houses and dedicated land to serve as a burial ground for Black residents. Gallipolis is a chartered village and the county seat of Gallia.

properties.Name: Gist Settlements
properties.Summary: Gist Settlements were communities established by former slaves of Samuel Gist who were freed following his final will of 1808 and death in 1815. Around 350 former slaves from Gist's plantation in Virgina moved to Ohio where they created farming communities initially in Erie County, and then later in Adams, Brown, and Highland Counties.

properties.Name: Guinea (Captina)
properties.Summary: Guinea was an important free Black settlement along the Underground Railroad. Alexander "Sandy" Harper had owned 300+ acres of land in Belmont County and established a Black abolitionist and farming community. The Bethel A. M. E. church was built in 1864. In 2014 people began efforts to restore the Captina A.M.E. cemetery.

properties.Name: Harveysburg
properties.Summary: Harveysburg was a town established by white Quakers William and Elizabeth Harvey. The two founded a school for the education of free Black children called, Harvey Free Negro School. The school operated until 1909. This does not appear to be a Black Town.

properties.Name: New Bremen
properties.Summary: New Bremen was one of several historic towns established by the Randolph Freed People. In 1846 the Randolph Freed People traveled from Virginia to retrieve their land inheritance and establish a community at New Bremen. The free Blacks were met by white mobs when they arrived. They left New Bremen for Rossville.

properties.Name: Poke Patch
properties.Summary: Poke Patch was a free Black agricultural settlement in Lawrence County Ohio from the 1820s to the early 1900s.

properties.Name: Ripley
properties.Summary: Ripley was an important site of the Underground Railroad. The town was established in 1822 by white Quaker abolitionist John Rankin. John Parker, a free Black man, was a central figure for the Underground Railroad and Ripley-based abolitionist movement. His house is marked as a historic site.

properties.Name: Stafford
properties.Summary: Stafford was incorporated in 1839 by a white abolitionist. As early as 1820 a small community of free Black people lived there. The population increased until the 1850s until it began a long decline until the 1960s.

properties.Name: Wilberforce
properties.Summary: Wilberforce, Ohio was the site of the first historically Black college in the US. Wilberforce University was founded in 1856 by the AME Church. This entry may be a duplicate for Wilberforce Colony in Canada which was established by free Black migrants from Cincinnati

properties.Name: Marshall Town (Marshalltown)
properties.Summary: Marshall Town was one of four historic towns established by the Randolph Freepeople (former slaves of the Randolph Plantation in Virginia). John Randolph wrote in his will that 383 slaves would be freed upon his death and given land in Ohio to settle. It was established on October 16, 1847 when Simon and Stephen Gillard, Lott Hill, and William Young (all part of the Randolph Freed People) purchased land from John and Sarah Marshall.

properties.Name: Hanktown
properties.Summary: Hanktown was one of four historic towns established by the Randolph Freedpeople (former slaves of the Randolph Plantation in Virginia). John Randolph wrote in his will that 383 slaves would be freed upon his death and given land in Ohio to settle. In 1846 (thirteen years after Randolph's death), Judge William Leigh, lawyer Francis Scot Key, and Bishop Meade facilitated the freeing of the Randolph slaves. They purchased between 2,000-3,200 acres of land in Mercer County, Ohio. Former slaves over the age of 40 were to be given at least 10 acres of land. When the Randolph Freed People arrived to claim these lands they were met by white mobs, so many never fully claimed their inheritance.

properties.Name: Rossville
properties.Summary: Rossville was the most successful of the four historic settlements established by the Randolph Freed People. On Feb 18,1857, William Rial purchased lot #13 in Rossville from a white landowner named W.W. McFarland. The African Jackson Cemetery (in what is now known as Piqua) marks the site of this town.

properties.Name: Rumley
properties.Summary: Joel and Wesley Going purchased 400 acres of land in 1830 and established Rumley. Other free Blacks such as members of the Randolph Freed People also joined the community.

properties.Name: Wren
properties.Summary: Wren village was a free Black settlement established in 1837 in Van Wert County, Ohio.

properties.Name: Lincoln Heights
properties.Summary: Lincoln Heights is a village in the Cinncinati suburbs. A middle class Black community developed beginnning in 1923 when the Haley-Livingston Land Company of Chicago sold lots of land to black families.

properties.Name: Urbancrest
properties.Summary: Urbancrest is an incorporated village in Franklin County, Ohio. It was established as a Black Town in the 1890s when Samuel and Ella Quinichett first built their home on the corner of First Avenue and Popular Street, now called John Cooley Drive in 1889. The Union Baptist Church was established in 1892 out of Samuel and Ella's home.

properties.Name: Arkansas Colored
properties.Summary: Located in southern Chickasaw Nation territory, Arkansas Colored no longer exists today but had a post office from around 1895 to 1912. It was potentially founded in 1867 by Creek freedman.

properties.Name: Bailey
properties.Summary: This Grady County settlement is said to have been an organized town. Bailey was located in Chickasaw Territory near Rush Creek. (71). Declined by 1962 (74)

properties.Name: Boggy Bend
properties.Summary: A no longer present community in Atoka County. There is little information about Boggy Bend beyond the town name beyond that it most likely have flooded.

properties.Name: Boley
properties.Summary: Boley is one of the largest and most popular black towns in Oklahoma. It is located in Creek Nation and had over 4,000 people by 1911. The town was vibrant with businesses, churches, schools, and more during its heyday. Boley has a Historic District that was added to the NRHP in 1975. The town hosts the annual Boley Rodeo which is one of the oldest black rodeos in the country. Wiki.

properties.Name: Bookertee
properties.Summary: Bookertee receives its namesake from Booker T. Washington. The community is said to have peaked around 1920 before its decline. It also seems to have had a Bookertee newspaper in circulation while the town existed.

properties.Name: Brooksville
properties.Summary: Brooksville is a Pottawatomie County black town that is still in existence. The town was first called Sewell after a white doctor who owned surrounding land before the current namesake was granted which stems from the first black resident there in 1912. It had a post office, school and church. Wiki.

properties.Name: Canadian Colored
properties.Summary: Near a supply spot during Civil War point that as called Canadian Depot. Eventually it went from  Canadian Colored Town to simply  Canadian Colored. Associated with Creek and African-Creek populations. Not to be confused with Canadian, OK to the northeast.

properties.Name: Chase
properties.Summary: According to the source, the town was established in 1903 but changed its name to Beland in 1908, niether of which survived. The coordinates are showing several miles northwest of Muskogee but source says it is "8 miles southwest of Muskogee."

properties.Name: Cimmaron
properties.Summary: There is a Cimarron County (note the spelling) that sits at the end of OK's panhandle and surrounds Boise City, but it is very far from the given coordinates. One source says Cimmaron City existed but no history of African Americans. Another Cimmaron mentioned in second source about a short lived black community west in Kingfisher. More research required.

properties.Name: Clarksville
properties.Summary: According to the listed oral history, Clarksville was a southwest Wagoner County town that lied south of Porter. Several first hand accounts are floating around the internet of African Americans who lived there at some point. Unsourced Wiki page is where the coords are from

properties.Name: Clearview
properties.Summary: Clearview is an Okfuskee County town that is still in existence and still majority black. The town was established near a railroad and grew into a town of several hundred people by the 1910s. It had a post office and other businesses along with churches and a school. Wiki.

properties.Name: Douglas
properties.Summary: Potentially in Garfield County, though the OHS sources mentions nothing about African Americans. Either way the town does not exist as a black town today.

properties.Name: Earlsboro
properties.Summary: Referred to as "Earlsborough" before 1895, the town is named after James Earls, an African American barber who had served under a Confederate general. According to source, Earlsboro had a rough reputation of being an illegal liquor town. In the mid 1920s the town struck oil and eventually had a school district, churches and businesses. Wiki.

properties.Name: Emanuel
properties.Summary: Virtually nothing coming up beyond the name. Coordinates do not match with the OK Historical Society (OHS) map which shows Emanuel in Blaine County closer to 35.730126, -98.468574 (approximately)

properties.Name: Ferguson
properties.Summary: Ferguson was established on the Canadian River North in Blaine County. It was advertised by a group of African Americans from the nearby town of Watonga for other African Americans. One source says that the town was 12 miles north of Watonga but coords don't match. Looks closer to (36.086319, -98.406175) according to OHS map.

properties.Name: Foreman
properties.Summary: According sources, Foreman was a town that was settled by two brothers wealthy by the last name of Foreman. One of the brothers, Zach Foreman, was a baseball player for the Kansas City Monarchs. Dissertation source says the town is 15 miles north of Spiro and Google maps gives this point: 35.332873, -94.637618

properties.Name: Gibson Station
properties.Summary: Mentioned in Dissertation source as a town that existed: "Gibson Station's existence can be traced to 1870, when it was a vicious little tent town, a rail construction camp, where the scum of the frontier collected" (65). Located south of Wagoner between Wagoner and Okay in Wagoner County. There is also a Gibson Station in Muskogee Co.

properties.Name: Grayson
properties.Summary: Grayson was once located in Okmulgee County before it changed to present day McIntosh County. Once known as "Wildcat," the town had a peak of around 400 people in the early 20th century and had general stores, drug stores, blacksmiths, and more. Sources on Grayson tell of its positive reputation. It is still majority black today. Wiki.

properties.Name: Greenwood, Tulsa
properties.Summary: The Greenwood District was a thriving black community that settled within the borders of Tulsa in the early 20th century by O.W. Gurley. This Black Wallstreet had an incredible ammount of businesses, including night clubs, hotels, banks and many more. It was the site of the Tulsa Massacre of 1912 which claimed anywhere from 75-300 lives. Archaeolgists are currently researching a mass grave to further understand the true number of African Americans who died from this act of terrorism. The district is NRHP affiliated. Wiki.

properties.Name: Haney
properties.Summary: Nothing in any sources

properties.Name: Homer
properties.Summary: Potentially one book with the passing mention of the town, with other scattered sources of people being born there. Mentioned in OHS, All Black Towns source and shown on map east of Tatums in Carter County.

properties.Name: Huttonville
properties.Summary: Little information except from one (uncited) source which states that Huttonville was started by Joesph Hutton, Sr. in the early 1900s, McIntosh County. It says that descendants relocated elsewhere in Oklahoma and to California.

properties.Name: Iconium
properties.Summary: Located in SE Logan County, according to OHS source. Not listed on main sources. The Logan Co. Historical Society blog post says that it was 3 miles NE of Meridian which is close to current coords. According to another source, the town may have been called "Main" after a man named George W. Main.

properties.Name: IXL
properties.Summary: IXL (also stylized as I.X.L) is a newly-incorporated Okfuskee County settlement situated six miles northeast of Boley. It was most likely established in the early 1900s. There are multiple versions of how IXL got its name including the namesake stemming from the initals of the founders and it being shorthand for "I excel." Wiki.

properties.Name: Keywest
properties.Summary: OHS source shows a Keywest on the map in eastern-central Lincoln County. Not seeing any mention in sources for "Keywest" or "Key West". Coords drop at Key West cemetery south of Stroud and matches fairly closely to OHS map approximation.

properties.Name: Langston
properties.Summary: This still-existing, majority black town is named after John Mercer Langston who was a mixed-raced attorney, educator, and abolitionist who went on to become a US Representative. The town was advertised by another notable political figure, Edward P. McCabe. The town grew in the 1890s and eventually had a bank and school, and later, Langston University. Wiki.

properties.Name: Lee
properties.Summary: Coords lead to a Lee cemetery, about 20 miles east of Okmulgee Regional Airport in Muskogee County. It seems to match up with the OHS map. No other sources seem to list it except for OHS by name only.

properties.Name: Lewisville
properties.Summary: According to the Tolson source, Lewisville is a Haskell County that was founded by a man named J. E. Thompson about eight miles east of Kinta near Beaver Creek. It looks like this is incorrect, as there is a Lewisville 2 miles west of Kinta along Beaver Creek. The same source also says there was a Baptist Church there and Harris Chapel Baptist Church is present. Unclear if it is still black, since the church could still be active, though possibly mis-marked on the map.

properties.Name: Liberty
properties.Summary: Coords lead to Tulsa County but OHS source shows it in SW Noble County. Tolson source says Edward P. McCabe and some partners established this town and that it is 3 miles north of Perry (in Noble Co.). There is also a Liberty South of Tulsa at (35.856907, -95.979780). More research needed.

properties.Name: Lima
properties.Summary: One of the remaining 13 black-founded towns, Lima was founded by 1904. It is said that civil rights activist Virna Mae Canson grew up in this Seminole County town. Rosenwald Hall is recognized as a historic landmark on the National Register of Historic Places. It is currently no longer majority black. Wiki.

properties.Name: Lincoln (Lincoln City)
properties.Summary: Also called Lincoln City, was an early, short lived that only lasted a few years. A post office was established in 1889 and it was that same year that the population reached almost 300. It was in Kingfisher County and vanished by 1900. Listed coordinates are most likely incorrect, though there is a Lincoln County. May be closer to (35.951927, -97.778052)

properties.Name: Mabelle
properties.Summary: Coords drop off near Shroud, OK but no sources beyond listed source. There is an unrelated Mabelle Inn in Pawshuka.

properties.Name: Macedonia
properties.Summary: No mention of Macedonia in any sources. Coords land in the town of Muskogee, SE of Tulsa.

properties.Name: Mantu (Manitou?)
properties.Summary: Only mention is the 11th footnote in Tolson source that states the author couldn't substantiate the town. The town potentially could have had 100 people.

properties.Name: Marshalltown
properties.Summary: Also spelled "Marshall Town,"  this settlement likely existed prior to the 1870s, potentially even the 1860s. One source mentions that there was much racial tension between the African-Creeks (policemen) and Cherokee cattlemen, some leading to fatal instances during their clashes. Since it is said that the town existed between the Arkansas and Verdigris Rivers, the current listed coords are likely not correct. More likely (35.959143, -95.651804) near or in the town of Coweta. Not north of OK City in the town of "Marshall."

properties.Name: Melvin
properties.Summary: Not mentioned in any sources. Only one Roadside post about it most likely being in Cherokee County. Unclear where listed coordinates are from.

properties.Name: North Fork (Town) Colored
properties.Summary: Starting in the 1850s, this settlement was among the earliest of black settlements in the state. North Fork Colored was originally a Creek settlement that shifted into an all-black town by the 1900s. The town was connected to the Civil War and blacks suffered from a Confederate raid and fled.

properties.Name: Oberlin
properties.Summary: This town was a Bryan County community, right along the Texas border north of the Red River and near a still-named Oberlin Lake. Acording to first source, Oberlin's post office ran from 1897 to 1937. There is a listed Oberlin Cemetery still in existence (33.876954, -95.855080)

properties.Name: Overton
properties.Summary: According to Tolson source, Overton had a postmaster, mayor, and town marshals were all black by 1900. There is no information on where this community once existed.

properties.Name: Pleasant Valley
properties.Summary: Coordinates lead to Pleasant Valley Cemetery in Oklahoma City but another map is showing it being near the border of Payne County and Logan County. Source states that the settlement had a post office from 1904 to 1947.

properties.Name: Porter
properties.Summary: There's a town called Porter (also in Wagoner Co.) that seems to have been all white. While no sources are showing Porter, it is in a hotspot for black towns in between the Arkansas and Verdigris Rivers and is near Redbird and Tullahassee. More research necessary to see if this ever was a black town.

properties.Name: Redbird (Red Bird)
properties.Summary: Red Bird was established in the early 1900s and still exists as a majority-black town today. Its population peaked in the 1920s at about 300-400 people and was home to Creek Freedmen and other African Americans. Red Bird was a trading hub for black farmers in the area. It has two sites on the National Register of Historic Places: Red Bird City Hall and the Miller-Washington School.  Wiki.

properties.Name: Rentiesville
properties.Summary: Another one of the thirteen surviving majority-black towns, Rentiesville was founded by William Rentie and is located inside of Creek Nation. This town has major entanglements with the Civil War, namely the 1863 Battle of Honey Springs, which town hosts reenactments of. This battlefield is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Wiki. There is also another town called Rentie which may need to be added!

properties.Name: Rusk
properties.Summary: Mentioned in a source that it was a place that once existed in Okfuskee County. Listed coordinates land in a different county far away on a Rusk Cemetery.

properties.Name: Sanders
properties.Summary: According to OHS source map, this settlement is the furtherst north of all of the black towns. Coordinates land on a Sanders Cemetery which is also in Nowata County but it doesn't seem to be in the same location as suggested by map.

properties.Name: Slick
properties.Summary: Unclear if it was established as a black town first, though the town does exist and is incorporated. It is majority white today but seems to have had a segregated African American section. Founder Thomas B. Slick was white. Wiki. More research required.

properties.Name: Summit
properties.Summary: Summit is a Muskogee County settlement that remains a majority-black town. Founded by the turn of the 20th century, the namesake is said to have possibly derived from its relatively high elevation. The town boasts three NRHP-affiliated sites: W.E.B. DuBois School, St. Thomas Primitive Baptist Church, and the Reverend L.W. Thomas Homestead (no NRHP link). Wiki.

properties.Name: Taft
properties.Summary: Originally called "Twine," Taft is among the 13 remaining black towns. During the early 1900s, the community was heavily promoted as good place for African Americans to live and it also had two newspapers. By 1910 Taft had several general stores, a soda factory, hotels, a bank, and more. Taft City Hall is listed on the National Register of Historic Places along with several other historic sites. Wiki.

properties.Name: Tatums
properties.Summary: Tatums is referred to as a "historic Freedman's town" and is named after Mary Tatums, the town's first postmistress. As the town developed over the years, oil was struck in the 1920s which made a handful of the residents wealthy. The Bethel Missionary Baptist Church is NRHP-affiliated.  Wiki.

properties.Name: Tullahassee
properties.Summary: Tullahassee is recognized as the oldest surviving black town in Oklahoma. After the Creek Nation established a notable school, Creek freedmen eventually came to use it and the population grew larger. The town boasts one stie, the A. J. Mason Building, that is listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

properties.Name: Udora
properties.Summary: Coordinates lead to a Udora Cemetery in Blaine County, which matches with the listed source. Little information is available about this town beyond the name being mentioned as a place that once existed.

properties.Name: Vernon
properties.Summary: This rural town was founded by Edwin P. McCabe and named after an AME Bishop and educator named William Tecumseh Vernon. The town has one NRHP-affiliated site. Though it has a very low population, it has one site on the National Register of Historic Places and is among the remaining still-existing Black towns.

properties.Name: Wellston Colony
properties.Summary: It is said that the residents of Wellston Colony came from Texas and purchased 1,000 acres of land to grow cotton on. The nearby white community allegedly denied the existence of this settlement in order to prevent more African Americans from moving there. There is little additional information on the Black history of this location.

properties.Name: Wiley
properties.Summary: Wiley was a Black community in Johnston County, Oklahoma. There is a Wiley County Cemetery still on the map at the given coordinates and little additional information.

properties.Name: Wybark
properties.Summary: Wybark was a town which sat north of Muskogee within the Wagoner County boundry at the junction of multiple railway lines. William Lamb was its postmaster in 1890. One source states that an article from the Daily Oklahoman had stated: "A white man is not allowed to stop there after sunset and the negroes have everything their own way." The community declined by the 1940s and may have absorbed the community of North Fork during its time.

properties.Name: Wewoka
properties.Summary: This town was founded by African Seminole leader John Horse in the late 1840s. African and Seminole histories are heavily entangled here, with other notable Black-Seminole figures living there. While it is no longer composed of majority Black descendants, the town remains the headquarters for the Seminole Nation. The town of Wewoka has a half dozen sites listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

properties.Name: Yahola
properties.Summary: Yahola is shown on maps as being a northern Muskogee County town in between Taft and Haskell, directly south of the Arkansas River. Little information about the history of this community is available.

properties.Name: Zion
properties.Summary: Zion is listed as a previously all-black community, though the location thus far is conflicting. One source shows that the town was in eastern Kingfisher County (closer to 35.919806, -97.740128). Listed coordinates in Adair County where a different town "Zion" is listed.

properties.Name: Wilberforce Colony (Canada)
properties.Summary: Following racist attacks against Black residents in Cincinnati during the 1829 riots, thousands of Black people fled the area to Ontario, Canada. Black residents living in Cincinnati had already formed an organization by 1828 and were in conversation with a Canadian company about purchasing land. By 1830 they had acquired 400 acres and in 1831 they established Wilberforce Colony.

properties.Name: Dawn Settlement (Canada)
properties.Summary: Hstoric Black settlement started in 1841 by Josiah Henson who escaped slavery in Maryland and purchased 200 acres of land. It is also the location of Uncle Tom's Cabin Historic Site

properties.Name: Elgin/ Buxton (Canada)
properties.Summary: Elgin Association purchased land and subdivided plots for Black people to live. "The settlement was made of 9,000 acres of land, 6 miles in length and 3 miles in width, situated between the Great Western Railway and Lake Erie. The land was divided into farms of 50 acres each. Certain standards had to be maintained in the settlement regarding property conditions."

properties.Name: Vanport
properties.Summary: Vanport, Oregon is regarded as one of several Drowned Black Towns/Communities. The town was created as temporary wartime housing for Black soldiers during WWII. Some residents lobbied the Housing Authority of Portland to dismantle Vanport, likely due to issues of racism and classism masked under the guise of dilapidated or blighted structures. In 1948 a flood swept through the town. Delta Park sits on the site of where Vanport once was.

properties.Name: Bennettsville
properties.Summary: Bennettsville was established in 1819 as a cotton growing region that relied upon the labor of enslaved Black people. The town is named after former SC govenor Thomas Bennett Jr. This town was the site of the famous Denmmark Vessey revolt of 1822 which was a slave revolt modeled after the Haitin Revolution, however the revolt was suppressed when slave owners were given a tip. They arrested and hanged many of the organizers. This area seems to be part of the Low Country and Gullah heritages. From the mid 1800s into the 20th century there was a prominent Black business district called "The Gulf" which might be why this was regarded as a Black town. The Shiloh Baptist church was established in 1867 and the town remains majority Black to this day.

properties.Name: Myrtle Beach/ North Myrtle Beach
properties.Summary: In 1934 Black/Gullah Geechee costal peoples from SC and GA established a resort district in Myrtle Beach during the Jim Crow Era. The 1936 construction of the Intercoastal Waterway brought additional business to the area and in 1938 the town of North Myrtle Beach was incorporated. Location points to Charlie's Place

properties.Name: Atlantic Beach (The Black Pearl)
properties.Summary: Atlantic Beach was an all-Black beach resort established by Black people following the 1964 Civil Rights Act which removed formal race restrictions on beaches (segregated beaches). Atlantic Beach is north of the long term Black/Gullah coastal community in Myrtle Beach.

properties.Name: Lincolnville
properties.Summary: Lincolnville was established in the 1860s by seven Black men who moved from Charleston. The men pooled their resources and purchased land in "Pump Pond". The town was chartered in 1889 and it was named after President Lincoln.

properties.Name: Mitchelville
properties.Summary: In 1863 a group of escaped slaves established a town on the grounds of a former plantation on Hilton Head Island. There are efforts to reconstruct replicas of the structure built by the freedmen.

properties.Name: Promised Land
properties.Summary: Promised Land was a Black town established after the Civil War when a former plantation owner sold his lands to the SC Land Commission. The land was subdivided into lots and sold to Black people. Currently Promised Land is a census-designated place.

properties.Name: Free Hill
properties.Summary: Virgina Hill, the daughter of a wealthy plantation owner from NC, purchased 2 thousand acres of land that she left for her slaves upon freeing them. The slaves carried the surname 'Free Hill' or collectively 'Free Hills' once freed, which is where the town derives its name. The town declined in the 1960s and a historical marker remembers its location.

properties.Name: Hortense
properties.Summary: Hortense was a Black town established around a Louisville/Nashville Railroad stop. In 1895  the Hortense Baptist Church was built. Black laborers in the mines lived in this area. The town declined in the 1920s due to westward migration and decline in railroad traffic/service.

properties.Name: New Bedford
properties.Summary: This town is included in a list in the appendix (page 153) of Hamilton's book on Black Towns in Trans-Appalachia. There is a county named Bedford in TN but it is unclear if that was the location of the town Hamilton references.

properties.Name: Africa (Webb or St. John's)
properties.Summary: Africa was a town formed by former slaves in East Texas near the Louisiana border in Shelby county. It is also referred to as St. Johns, after St. John's Baptist Church, or Webb after one of the town's founders.

properties.Name: Andy (Cuney)
properties.Summary: Andey (present day Cuney) was a town founded by former slaves in Cherokee County. The name is derived from Andrew (Andy) Bragg who was the first Black land owner in the area. The town was established after the Civil War but gained prominence in 1902 when it became a railroad stop between Texas and New Orleans. The name Cuney is derived from Cuney Price, the son of a prominent Black politician. In 1983 the town was incorporated.

properties.Name: Barrett Station (Texas Century Farm)
properties.Summary: Founded by former slave, Harrison Barrett, who purchased land in 1889.

properties.Name: Booker
properties.Summary: Booker is listed in both K. Hamilton's (1991) and Q. Taylor's (1999) books on Black Towns. Booker is not in the Texas Freedom Colony Atlas and the description in Texas State Historical encylopedia does not mention it being a Black settlement or town. Perhaps it had another alias.

properties.Name: Cologne (Perdido Community)
properties.Summary: Cologne Colony, a free Black town established by two former slaves, Jim Smith and George Washington, hadd many names during its existence. Initially the town was also referred to as Centerville due to its location between Golia and Victoria. The town was also referred to as Ira Station based on a railway stop that was in the town. When a post office was erected under the name Cologne, that became the town's name.

properties.Name: Deep Ellum
properties.Summary: Deep Ellum (or Deep Elm) was established by former slaves following the Civil War. The Black town declined after WWII. In the 1980s the area was redeveloped into an entertainment and arts district in downtown Dallas.

properties.Name: Ellis Alley Enclave
properties.Summary: In the 1860s two landownders subdivided 0.7-acres in east San Antonio into 25 lots that were sold exclusively to newly emancipated Black Americans. The area known as the "Black Eastside" was devastated during the 1970s due to highway construction and urban renewal.

properties.Name: Elm Thicket
properties.Summary: Elm Thicket was a rural African American community established near Dallas sometime around 1900 (according to Texas Freedom Colony Atlas)

properties.Name: Fourth Ward (Freedmen's Town)
properties.Summary: The Fourth Ward was created as a subdivision of Houston when the city was chartered in 1839. Black institutions like the Black Methodist Church were established as early as 1851. After the Civil War former slaves moved to the area and by the late 19th and 20th century its was it was a central site in Black Houston.

properties.Name: Independence Heights
properties.Summary: Indepdenence Heights is a Black district/ Freedom Colony in north Houston. In 1905 the Wright Land Company began developing the area and Black residents began purchasing homes (some of which they built as contractors?). The town quickly grew to 600 residents and in 1915 the Black community incorporated (the first Black incorporated municipality in Texas). In 1929 the town was annexed by the city of Houston. Urban renewal and the development of the 610 Loop devastated the Black community. In 2017 plans to expand the I-45 again threatened the Black community. The Independence Heights community has been resisting this kind of racially-targeted development and displacement.

properties.Name: Kendleton
properties.Summary: Kendleton was formed in the 1860s when William E. Kendall divided his plantation and sold the land as farms to former slaves.

properties.Name: Little Egypt
properties.Summary: Little Egypt was established by former slaves Jeff and Hanna Hill when they were emancipated in 1865. The Hills were deeded land from their former owner. In 1870 they built little Egypt Baptist church for which the town became named after. In 1961 the community was poached for redevelopment into a Dallas retail center. In 1962 the 30-35 acres of land was purchased by commerical developers and some 200 Black residents were relocated to Oak Cliff or in Rockwall County.

properties.Name: Mill City
properties.Summary: Mill City likely refers to the New City Cotton Mills, an all-Black cotton mill enterprise that was pursued following a 1900 business convention at the Colored Fair. The Colored Fair was a prominent event for Black Dallas businessmen and elite. Construction of the mill began in 1901 and it opened in 1902. The majority of mill workers were Black women and girls (Garrett-Scott, 2012). By 1906 the mill was bankrupt and was sold in 1907. This area might also be referred to as Lagow. The current majority Black neighborhood called Mill City in south Dallas that likely connects to this history, though there were a number of cotton mills in the area. References to Colored Fair, Colored People's Day, would be useful in locating this history. Location points to Mill Place near Wahoo Park where the mill may have been and where the Mill City neighborhood is.

properties.Name: Moore Station
properties.Summary: Moore Station is a town named after former slaves Anderson and Lucinda Moore. In 1876 they donated land to build a Methodist church and a school. MMany other free Black people moved to the area.

properties.Name: Neylandville
properties.Summary: Neylandville was established by James (Jim) Brigham who purchased his family's freedom from their owner, Robert Neyland, and later established a collective farming community by the 1880s. The town was an important educational center for Black children in the 1880s. The town incorporated in 1970.

properties.Name: Oldham
properties.Summary: Oldham is listed in books on Black Towns by Hamilton (1991) and Taylor (1999). The Black history of this town relates to a Black man named Henrick Arnold. Henrick Arnold was the son (and slave of?) his white father, Daniel Arnold. Henrick, the Arnold family, and the Arnold slaves moved from Mississippi to Texas in 1826. Henrick was never officially freed from his father's family, though he was regarded as free. Henrick had a daughter (Harriet) with another Arnold slave and she was considered his slave. Henrick acquired land after fighting in the Texas Revolution of 1835-1836. It appears that Henrick reserved his land for his white relatives. Henrick sold 640 acres of land to William Oldham in 1837. Oldham had established the largest plantation in the area. The town developed as a white town since then.

properties.Name: Peyton (Boardhouse)
properties.Summary: This town was established by Peyton Roberts in 1865. Peyton Roberts was enslaved in Lockhart Texas until gaining freedom following the Civil War. In 1865 he started a community for free Black people along Boardhouse Creek. Other freedmen from Virginia (William's plantation) also joined the community. They had gained public land through "preemption" until the policy ended in 1876. As late as 2000 there were still a small number of descendants living in the community.

properties.Name: Roberts (Quinlan)
properties.Summary: Roberts was listed as a Black Town in books by Hamilton (1991) and Taylor (1999). According to the Texas Historical Society, the town Roberts was named after TX govenor O. M. Roberts. In 1882 Roberts sold 100 acres of public land to Texas Central Railroad. Ten years later, in 1892, a train depot was built 1.5 miles away from Roberts. The name for the depot town that displaced Roberts is Quinlan (after George Austin Quinlan of the Texas Central Railroad).

properties.Name: Saint Johns Colony (Winn's Colony)
properties.Summary: In the 1870s Rev. John Henry Winn organized free Black families from Webberville to purchase land in Caldwell, Texas (north of Lockhart). In 1873, they built St. John Missionary Baptist Church and changed the name to St. John Colony.

properties.Name: Shankleville
properties.Summary: Shankleville was established by former slaves Jim and Winnie Shankle. Jim and Winnie were enslaved by separated owners in Kentucky and Tennessee. Winnie's owner moved to Texas and Jim escaped to meet her there. Jim was purchased by Winnie's owner. When they were freed after the Civil War, Jim acquired property. The Shakles and their descendents built churches, a sawmill, a gristmill, and a cotton gin, and a college (McBride College).

properties.Name: Tamina
properties.Summary: Tamina was a freedmen's colony started by former slaves who worked on the Houston and Great Northern Railroad. The town's name was intended to be Tammany (after Tammany Hall in NY) but someone wrote it as Tamina. It is still pronounced "Tammany" to people from the area.

properties.Name: Tenth Street Historic District
properties.Summary: Dallas' 12th District is the location of a longstanding freedmen's community established by former slaves in the area following the Civil War. Many may have been slaves from the cotton plantation of William Brown Miller.

properties.Name: Union City (Union Valley)
properties.Summary: Union City was listed as a Black Town in books by Hamilton (1991) and Taylor (1999).

properties.Name: Freedman's Village
properties.Summary: From 1863-1900 a free Black community existed in Arlington, VA where the grounds of the Pentagon and National Cemetery now stand. Freedman's Village was established at Arlington House (a plantation owned by Robert E. Lee's wife), by the federal government (Freedmen's Bureau?). It initially consisted of 50 houses (to be shared by 2 families each). Sojourner Truth worked as an educator there in 1864.

properties.Name: Pocahontas Island
properties.Summary: Pocahontas Island was a community were enslaved and free Black people lived since the 18th century. It was originally a port and then an island when a canal was built in the 1700s, until the canal was filled making the Island join the city of Petersburg. Petersburg was one of the largest slave markets in the area. By the 19th Century it was a freedom (or freedmen's) colony. Currently the population is down to 50 people from its height of 700 in the 20th century (Schneider, 2016).

properties.Name: Titustown
properties.Summary: Titustown was a Black community in/near Norfolk where Black people bought land in large numbers from a man named John Stroud. The town is named after Stroud's son, Augustus Titus Stroud. Many of the Black residents worked for the Navy Shipyards and there were several dozen Black businesses.

properties.Name: Truxton
properties.Summary: Truxton was a planned 87-acre, Black-only community with 250 houses to serve Black Navy Shipyard workers. White shipyard workers lived south of the Navy Yard, whereas Black workers were settled west of the Yard. In 1982 it was added to the National Register of Historic Places as the Historic Truxton District.

properties.Name: Bush Prairie (Tumwater)
properties.Summary: Bush Prairie (now Tumwater) was a community started by ex-slave and fur trader George Bush who migrated to the Northeast. Originally Bush sought to settle in Oregon however the state had laws prohibiting the presence of Black people. Bush and his family moved to Washington Territory near the Pugent Sound and established a 640 arcre homestead called, Bush Prairie. Bush was not formally given title to the lands he had purchased until 1855 due to racist laws. The area where the Bush's homestead was is now the Olympia airport.

properties.Name: Centerville (Centralia)
properties.Summary: In 1853 George Washington purchased 640 acres of land in Washington Territory after several unsuccessful attempts of purchasing land as a Black man in the Midwest. In 1875 Washington formally applied to create a town called Centerville. In 1889 the town had 1000 residents. By 1893 the town began to decline due to the closing of iron works and lumbermills. Washington died in 1905. The town is now known as Centralia.

properties.Name: Institute
properties.Summary: In 1865 white plantation owner Samuel I. Cabell was killed by seven of his neighbors. His will had specified that his slave mistress Mary Barnes and their children should be freed upon his death and that his estate would go to them. In 1870 the courts granted Mary Barnes/Cabell the estate. The estate Mary Barnes Cabell and the Cabell children inherited became known as Cabell Farm and later Pinety Grove. In 1891 the West Virginia Colored Institute was created on the estate to educate Black children. The name 'Institute' is derrived from this school.

properties.Name: Tinkersville
properties.Summary: Tinkersville was a town formed by former slaves. Lewis Rice founded African Zion Baptist Church, the first black church  in West Virginia.

properties.Name: Cheyenne Valley
properties.Summary: Cheyenne Valley (near the town of Hillsboro) was the site of the largest Black rural town in Wisconsin. In 1855 a former slave from North Carolina, Walden Stewart, migrated to the area following the Fugitive Slave Act. A total of 150 Black residents lived in the area as farmers.

properties.Name: Stantonville (Chilton)
properties.Summary: Stantonville was a Black homestead community established by former slave Moses Stanton and his Black and Native American (Narragansett Indians) wife Catherine Ross Stanton in 1845. The Stantons had a grist and a saw mill. Once European settlers reached the area the name was changed to Chilton.

properties.Name: Pleasant Ridge (Grant County)
properties.Summary: Pleasant Ridge was a Black homestead community started by former Virginia slave, Charles Shepard in 1850. In 1848 Shepard's slaveowner Sarah Edmonds died and freed her slaves in her will. Charles and another former slave travelled with Edmond's nephew to work on minning in Wisconsin. Charles and Isaac eventually purchased 200 acres of land and were joined by other Black people freeing slavery from the south. The town grew to about 100 residents (50/50 Black and white) and Black residents owned 700 acres of land by 1895. In 1959 the last Black resident died. Pleasant Ridge is now known as Beetown.

properties.Name: Empire
properties.Summary: Black homestead community started by Charles and Rosetta Speese who left DeWitty, Nebraska for southeast WY in 1908. They claimed 320 acres of land through the Enlarged Homestead Act and other families joined them. By 1930 the town was gone and only 4 Black residents remained. The town was in Goshen County, WY (near the NE-WY state line). In 2020 a historical marker was placed at Dwyer Junction Rest Area on Interstate 25 north of Wheatland in Platte County to commemorate the town. Another historical marker is at Goshen County Homesteaders Museum in Torrington. Not sure if these coordinates are correct as this was listed under NE. The town was apparently 1 mile from the NE border.
